documents.title: Motion to Intervene
documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 1 of 9 FILED
 
 2018 Aug-27  PM 04:23
U.S. DISTRICT COURT
N.D. OF ALABAMA
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ALABAMA 
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
 
LAKEISHA CHESTNUT, et al.,   ) 
            ) 
  Plaintiffs,        ) 
            ) 
vs.             )  CASE NO. 2:18-CV-00907-KOB 
            ) 
JOHN H. MERRILL, etc.,     ) 
            ) 
  Defendant.      ) 
MOTION TO INTERVENE 
Comes now Alabama Senator Jim McClendon, as an Alabama Senator and 
member  of  the  Alabama  Legislatureโs  Permanent  Legislative  Committee  on 
Reapportionment, and pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 24, respectfully moves for leave 
to intervene as a defendant in his official capacity, and as grounds shows the 
following: 
THE INTERVENOR 
1.  Drawing  congressional  districts  is  the  duty  of  the  Alabama 
Legislature. Abbott v. Perez, 138 S.Ct. 2305, 2316 (June 25, 2018) (noting that 
โ[r]edistricting  is  โprimarily  the  duty  and  responsibility  of  the  Stateโโ).  To 
facilitate this and other redistricting activities, the Alabama Legislature created 
the Permanent Legislative Committee on Reapportionment. See Ala. Code ยงยง 29-
2-50 to -53. The Reapportionment Committee is responsible for the โpreparation 
and formulationโ of redistricting plans and the โreadjustment or alteration of โฆ 
congressional districtsโ for the State of Alabama.  Ala. Code ยง 29-2-52(c). See also 
 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 2 of 9
id. ยง 29-2-52(a)-(b) (charging the Reapportionment Committee with conducting 
a  continuous  study  of  โreapportionmentโ1  problems  and  reporting  to  the 
Legislature its findings and  recommendations)  and ยง 29-2-52(e) (empowering 
the Reapportionment Committee โto do and perform any such acts that may be 
necessary, desirable, or proper to carry out the purposes and objectivesโ of the 
statutes creating it). 
2.  Alabamaโs current seven congressional districts were drawn under 
the  aegis  of  the  Reapportionment  Committee,  were  passed  by  the  Alabama 
Legislature as S.B. 484 (now codified at Ala. Code ยง 17-14-70), were signed into 
law by the Governor, were precleared under then-enforceable Section 5 of the 
Voting Rights Act by United States Attorney General Eric Holder2 on November 
21, 2011, and have since been enforced as the congressional districts of Alabama. 
These districts will as of course be redrawn in 2021 after the 2020 Census results 
are  released  in  (probably)  February  2021,  in  preparation  for  Congressional 
elections in 2022.3 
                                                 
1  The  terms  โreapportionmentโ  and  โredistrictingโ  have  been  used 
interchangeably  by  the  Alabama  Legislature.  See,  e.g.,  Permanent  Legislative 
Committee on Reapportionment, Redistricting History, http://www.legislature. 
state.al.us/aliswww_LCC/ISD/ALReap_History.aspx (last visited July 23, 2018).  
2 According to press reports, Mr. Holder is the chair of the National Democratic 
Redistricting  Committee,  which  in  the  guise  of  the  National  Redistricting 
Foundation  is  โbackingโ  the  Chestnut  case  and  similar  cases  in  Georgia  and 
Louisiana. See https://www.apnews.com/d30b289c43f543 079555304f2be53b6a 
(last visited July 23, 2018).
 
3  The  2021  regular  session  of  the  Alabama  Legislature,  at  which  redrawing 
congressional districts could be accomplished, will open on Tuesday, February 
12, 2021. 
257410.1 
2 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 3 of 9
3.  Jim McClendon is a resident and citizen of St. Clair County and is 
the  State  Senator  for  Senate  District  11  (Shelby,  St.  Clair,  and  Talladega 
Counties). In 2011, when the 2010 Census results were released, Sen. McClendon 
was a member of the Alabama House of Representatives and was the House Chair 
of  the  Legislatureโs  Permanent  Committee  on  Reapportionment.  Then-Rep. 
McClendon authored the congressional districts plan, then known as the โ2010 
McClendon Congressional Districts 1โ plan, that became ยง 17-14-70. (Then-Rep. 
McClendon and Senate Reapportionment Committee Co-Chair Gerald Dial also 
prepared the 2012 redistricting plans for the Alabama Legislature and the State 
Board of Education and shepherded them through the Alabama Legislature.) 
THE LITIGATION 
4.  Plaintiffs allege that in 2011 Alabama engaged in vote dilution in 
Congressional  Districts  1,  2,  3,  and  7,  or  some  combination  of  them.  See 
Complaint, doc. 1, ยถ 3 (alleging that African American voters were assigned to 
District 1, 2, or 3 on the basis of their race).  
5.  Plaintiffs  ask  the  Court  to  enjoin  enforcement  of  the  current 
congressional  districts  and  to  order  Alabama  to  adopt  a  new  congressional 
districts plan that includes two majority-black districts. Doc. 1, prayer for relief. 
ARGUMENT FOR INTERVENTION 
 
6.  Sen. McClendon should be permitted to intervene under Fed. R. Civ. 
P.  24(b)(1)(B), which provides, in pertinent part, as follows: 
 
257410.1 
3 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 4 of 9
(1) In General. On a timely motion, the court may permit anyone 
to intervene who: 
   โฆ 
 
    (B) has a claim or defense that shares with the main action a       
common question of law or fact.  
 
7.  Sen. McClendon has โa claim or defense that shares with the main 
action a common question of law or fact.โ Id.  Sen. McClendon seeks intervention 
to assert factual and legal defenses to defend the Reapportionment Committeeโs 
and Legislatureโs redistricting activities, to argue for the  constitutionality and 
lawfulness of ยง 17-14-70, and to argue against the remedy for which plaintiffs 
pray, which would impose on the prerogatives and duties of the Reapportionment 
Committee and the Legislature.  
8.   โThe  Constitution  entrusts  States  with  the  job  of  designing 
congressional  districts.โ  Cooper  v.  Harris,  137  S.Ct.  1455,  1463  (2017).  As  a 
former and prospective future Chair of the Reapportionment Committee, and 
author of โ2010 McClendon Congressional  Districts 1โ and other redistricting 
plans, Sen. McClendon is particularly well informed to contribute to the defense 
of  the  Stateโs  congressional  redistricting  plan,  and  to  assist  the  Court  in 
determining  whether  it  should  intrude  upon  the  Legislatureโs  redistricting 
authority. See Miller v. Johnson, 515 U.S. 900, 916 (1995).  
9.  In addition, no party in this case has Sen. McClendonโs redistricting 
experience,  and  it  will  benefit  the  quality  of  litigation  and,  if  necessary,  any 
remedy to have a party in the case who is experienced in redistricting.  If the 
257410.1 
4 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 5 of 9
Court  were  to  order  Alabama  to  draw  new  congressional  districts,  Sen. 
McClendon would necessarily be at the center of that activity.  
10.  Absent intervention, Sen. McClendon will not be able to protect the 
interests  of  the  Reapportionment  Committee  in  this  action,  and  through  the 
Reapportionment Committee, the interests of the Legislature, in protecting the 
congressional districts drawn in 2012, and in defending the Reapportionment 
Committeeโs and the Legislatureโs redistricting prerogatives. 
11.  Sen.  McClendon  also  seeks  intervention  under  Fed.  R.  Civ.  P. 
24(b)(2), which states: 
(2) By a Government Officer of Agency. On timely motion, the 
court  may  permit  a  โฆ  state  governmental  officer  or  agency  โฆ  to 
intervene if a partyโs claim or defense is based on: 
 
  (A) a statute โฆ administered by the officer or agency; or 
 
(B) any regulation, order, requirement, or agreement issued  
or made under the statute โฆ.  
 
12.  Chestnutโs  lawsuit  challenges  the  manner  in  which  Alabamaโs 
Legislature  exercised its duty to draw congressional districts, i.e., challenges how 
the Reapportionment Committee fulfilled its statutory  duties under Ala. Code 
ยง 29-2-52(c)    to  draw  new  congressional  districts.  In  addition,  defending  the 
Stateโs  congressional  districts  will  include  defending  the  Reapportionment 
Committeeโs Guidelines, which are requirements that established priorities for 
drawing districts in 2011. Thus, Chestnutโs lawsuit requires a defense based on a 
statute and a requirement made under that statute. 
257410.1 
5 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 6 of 9
13.  Consequently,  Sen.  McClendon  should  be  permitted  to  intervene 
pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b).  See e.g., Graham v. Thornburgh, 207 F. Supp. 
2d  1280,  1285  (D.  Kan.  2002)  (in  an  action  challenging  the  plan  for 
apportionment of congressional districts in the State of Kansas, district court 
permitted state legislator and Chairman of the House Redistricting Committee, 
who appeared โon behalf of himself as a legislator and as Chairman of the House 
Redistricting Committeeโ to intervene pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b); Scott v. 
U.S.  Depโt  of  Justice,  920  F.  Supp.  1248,  1250  (M.D.  Fla.  1996)  (granting 
intervention by both houses of Floridaโs Legislature in a legislative districting 
case), affโd sub nom, Lawyer v. Depโt of Justice, 521 U.S. 567 (1997). 
14.  Allowing  Sen.  McClendon  to  intervene  would  be  consistent  with 
prior federal court decisions. A predecessor of the Reapportionment Committee 
was permitted to intervene in the voting rights case known as Sims v. Amos, 336 
F. Supp. 924, as supplemented, 340 F. Supp. 691 (M.D. Ala. 1972), affโd, 409 U.S. 
942  (1972).  More  recently,  the  Reapportionment  Committee  was  allowed  to 
intervene as a defendant in the consolidated cases that made a timely challenge 
to Alabama legislative districts, Alabama Legislative Black Caucus v. State of 
Alabama,  case  no.  2:12-CV-691  (three-judge  court)  and  Newton  v.  State  of 
Alabama, case no. 2:12-cv-1081 (three-judge court), doc. 90 (March 3, 2013) 
(granting motion to intervene as defendants), see generally Alabama Legislative 
Black Caucus v. State of Alabama, 989 F.Supp.2d 1227, 1238 (M.D. Ala. 2013). 
   
257410.1 
6 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19   Filed 08/27/18   Page 7 of 9
TIMELINESS 
15.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 24 requires that a motion to intervene be timely. This 
case was commenced on June 13, 2018, and on July 23, 2018 the plaintiffs filed 
an amended complaint, doc. 14. A trial date has not yet been set, and no discovery 
has occurred.  Given that this action is still in a very early stage, this motion is 
timely. 
NO PREJUDICE OR DELAY 
  16.  Intervention  or  participation  by  Sen.  McClendon  will  not  unduly 
delay or prejudice the adjudication of the original partiesโ rights.  
NOTICE AND PLEADING 
  17.  Pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(c), Sen. McClendon has served this 
motion on all parties. Sen. McClendon has attached to this motion his proposed 
response to the amended complaint. See Exhibit 1.  
NO OBJECTION BY THE DEFENDANT  
  18.  Counsel for Sen. McClendon is authorized to represent to the Court 
that the Secretary of State Merrill does not object to Sen. McClendon intervening 
in this action. 
CONCLUSION 
19.  Based  on  the  foregoing,  pursuant  to  Fed.  R.  Civ.  P.  24,  Sen. 
McClendon respectfully moves the Court to grant this motion to intervene.  
   
257410.1

documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 1 of 50 FILED
 
 2018 Aug-27  PM 04:23
U.S. DISTRICT COURT
N.D. OF ALABAMA
 
 
 
 
EXHIBIT 1 
 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 2 of 50
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ALABAMA 
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
 
LAKEISHA CHESTNUT, et al.,   ) 
            ) 
  Plaintiffs,        ) 
            ) 
vs.             )  CASE NO. 2:18-CV-00907-KOB 
            ) 
JOHN H. MERRILL,      ) 
            ) 
  Defendant,      ) 
            ) 
vs.            ) 
            ) 
SEN. JIM MCCLENDON,    ) 
            ) 
  Intervenor-Defendant.  ) 
 
MOTION TO DISMISS THE AMENDED COMPLAINT 
Comes now Alabama Senator Jim McClendon, as an Alabama Senator and 
member  of  the  Alabama  Legislatureโs  Permanent  Legislative  Committee  on 
Reapportionment, and pursuant to Rule 12, Fed.R.Civ.P. respectfully moves the 
Court to dismiss the amended complaint, doc. 14, and in support of this motion 
shows the following:  
   
 
257472.1

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 3 of 50
THE COURT LACKS SUBJECT-MATTER JURISDICTION1 
 
   As the Court knows, 28 U.S.C ยง 2284(a) requires federal constitutional 
challenges to a stateโs congressional districts be heard by a three-judge court. To 
avoid a three-judge court, the plaintiffs (hereinafter collectively, โChestnutโ) have 
brought their challenge under ยง 2 of the Voting Rights Act only โ i.e., they make a 
statutory challenge, not a constitutional one - and have uniquely eschewed claims 
under  the  14th  and  15th  Amendments,  which  otherwise  uniformly  are  made 
together with such ยง 2 claims.  See Page v. Bartels, 248 F.3d 175, 190 (3rd. Cir. 
2001)  (observing  that  โstatutory  Voting  Rights  Act  challenges  to  statewide 
legislative  apportionment  are  generallyโ  so  โinextricably  intertwined  with 
constitutional challenges to such apportionmentโ that they โshould be considered 
a single โactionโ within the meaning of ยง 2284(a)โ); see also Johnson v. Ardoin2, 
No. 18-cv-625-SDD-EWD (M.D. La. July 31, 2018) (Memorandum in Support of 
                                                 
1   Sen. McClendon questions whether this case should be heard by a single-
judge or a three-judge district court, but regardless of the ruling on that issue, 
this (single-judge) Court has jurisdiction to dismiss this case if it determines that 
the  plaintiffsโ  claims  are  โwholly  insubstantial  or  completely  without  merit.โ 
United States v. St. Landry Parish School Board, 601 F.2d 859, 863 (5th Cir. 
1979) (re ยง 5 of the Voting Rights Act); accord Kalson v. Paterson, 542 F.3d 281, 
287 (2nd Cir. 2008) (โAlthough 28 U.S.C ยง 2284 is jurisdictional, it has long been 
held that a single judge may dismiss a claim that must normally be heard by a 
three-judge court if it is insubstantial.โ).  
2   The instant case, Chestnut, is one of three cases challenging congressional 
districts reportedly filed under the aegis of the National Democratic Redistricting 
Committee,  dba  the  National  Redistricting  Foundation.  See 
https://www.apnews.com/d30b289c43f543079555304f2be53b6a  (last  visited 
July 23, 2018). The other two are Dwight v. Kemp, No. 1:18-cv-2869 (N.D. Ga. 
June 13, 2018) and Johnson v. Ardoin, No. 3:13-cv-625-SDD-EWD (M.D. Ga. 
June 13, 2018). All three cases make the same basic legal argument under ยง 2 of 
the VRA, and make no parallel constitutional claims.
 
2 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 4 of 50
Defendantโs Motion to Dismiss a parallel challenge to Louisianaโs congressional 
districts, p. 3, n. 1 (pointing out the rarity of reapportionment challenges that do 
not include claims under the 14th and 15th Amendments as well as ยง 2 of the 
Voting Rights Act))(attached as Exhibit A).  
  The argument that this statutory challenge should be heard by a three-
judge court comes down to the language of ยง 2284(a) and what Congress knew 
when it last amended that statute. The argument that Congress meant for all 
challenges to congressional reapportionment to be heard by three-judge courts is 
ably  made  by  the  Attorney  General  of  Louisiana  in  its  motion  to  dismiss  in 
Johnson  v.  Ardoin,  Ex.  A,  pp.  2-6,  which  Sen.  McClendon  adopts  with  the 
additional observation that Chestnutโs argument ultimately rests on the sort of 
โmagic languageโ that the Supreme Court disavowed in Abbott v. Perez, 138 S.Ct. 
2305 (Jun. 25, 2018). In that case the Supreme Court was required to determine, 
for jurisdictional purposes, if a three-judge courtโs order was an injunction - and 
thus appealable - even though the three-judge court did not call it an injunction. 
Doing so required the Supreme Court to consider the wording of two statutes 
relating to interlocutory appeals, 28 U.S.C. ยง 1253 and ยง 1292(a)(1):  
The orders in these cases fall within ยง 1253 [allowing appeal of โan 
order granting โฆ an interlocutory โฆ injunctionโ]. To be sure, the 
District  Court  did  not  call  its  orders  โinjunctionsโ  โ  in  fact,  it 
disclaimed  the  term  โฆ  but  the  label  attached  to  an  order  is  not 
dispositive. We have previously made clear that where an order has 
the โpractical effectโ of granting or denying an injunction, it should be 
treated as such for purposes of appellate jurisdiction. โฆ We applied 
this test in Carson [v. American Brands, Inc., 450 U.S. 79 (1981)], 
holding  that  an  order  that  declined  to  enter  a  consent  decree 
3 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 5 of 50
prohibiting  certain  conduct could  be appealed under ยง 1292(a)(1) 
because  it  was  the  practical  equivalent  of  an  order  denying  an 
injunction and threatened serious and perhaps irreparable harm if 
not immediately reviewed.  
 
This  โpractical  effectโ  rule  serves  a  valuable  purpose.  If  an 
interlocutory injunction is improperly granted or denied, much harm 
can occur before the final decision in the district court. Lawful and 
important  conduct  may  be  barred,  and  unlawful  and  harmful 
conduct  may  be  allowed  to  continue.  Recognizing  this,  Congress 
authorized interlocutory appellate review for such orders. But if the 
availability of interlocutory review depended on the district courtโs 
use  of  the  term  โinjunctionโ  or  some  other  particular  language, 
Congressโs scheme would be frustrated. The harms that Congress 
wanted to avoid could occur so long as the district court was careful 
about its terminology. The โpractical  effectโ inquiry prevents such 
manipulation. 
 
 
Abbott,  138  S.Ct.  at  2319-2320.  The  Court  then  explained  that  although  its 
โโpractical  effectโ  approachโ  was  developed  in  cases  dealing  with  ยง  1292(a)(1) 
[allowing  appeals  of  โ[i]nterlocutory  orders  โฆ  granting  injunctionsโ],  the 
approach also applies to ยง 1253: 
The provisions are also textually interlocked. Section 1292(a)(1) does 
not apply where โdirect review may be had in the Supreme Court, 
i.e., where ยง 1253 applies. If the โpractical effectsโ test applied under 
ยง 1292(a)(1) but not ยง 1253, the consequences would be unfortunate 
and strange. We would have to identify the magic language needed 
for an order to qualify as an order granting or denying an injunction 
.... 
 
Abbott, 138 S.Ct. at 2320.  
  Just as with the interlocutory appeal statutes the Supreme Court discussed 
in Abbott, challenges to congressional districts under the Constitution and the 
Voting Rights Act are interrelated. Page, 248 F.3d at 190 (โMore significantly, it 
4 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 6 of 50
is clear that questions regarding  the legitimacy of an  apportionment scheme, 
whether  under  the  Constitution  or  the  Voting  Rights  Act  โฆ  are  โintimately 
relatedโโฆ.โ). The amended complaint shows ignoring this interrelation frustrates 
Congressโ  reason  in  1976  for  continuing  to  require  that  challenges  to 
congressional districts be heard by three-judge courts. As the relevant Senate 
Report  said:  โThe  bill  preserves  three-judge  courts  for  cases  involving 
congressional reapportionment โฆ because it is the judgment of the committee 
that these issues are of such importance that they ought to be heard by a three-
judge court โฆ.โ S. REP. 94-204, at 1996 (1975).  
  The โpractical effectโ of a successful challenge to congressional districts is 
the same regardless of whether the claim is brought under ยง2 or under the 14th 
and  15th Amendments. To ignore this fact would  grant Chestnut an  end run 
around  the procedure that  Congress intended  to be used when  congressional 
districts  are  challenged:  a  three-judge  court  and  quick  direct  appeal  to  the 
Supreme Court.3 Because the practical effects of these challenges are the same, 
they should be treated the same. Page, 248 F.3d at 190 (โ[W]e conclude that 
because  statutory  Voting  Rights  Act  challenges  to  statewide  legislative 
apportionment  are  generally  inextricably  intertwined  with  constitutional 
                                                 
3   Given the importance of the interests at issue, it is probably inevitable that 
the decision of the district court will be appealed by one side or the other, and for 
this  reason  Chestnutโs  refusal  to  take  advantage  of  the  far  speedier  appeal 
available under ยง 2284(a) is a continuation by different means of her inexcusable 
delay in commencing this lawsuit, which is addressed below.  
5 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 7 of 50
challenges to such apportionment, those claims should be considered a single 
โactionโ within the meaning of ยง 2284(a)โ). 
  On a related point, in Chestnutโs response to Secretary Merrillโs motion to 
dismiss, Chestnut responds to the argument (not made by Secretary Merrill)  that 
when Congress narrowed the scope of ยง 2284 in 1976, it did so under the belief 
that all statewide reapportionment challenges would be constitutional, meaning 
that  the  language  Congress  used  -  โwhen  an  action  is  filed  challenging  the 
constitutionality  of  the  apportionment  of  congressional  districts  or  the 
apportionment of any statewide legislative bodyโ โ did not reflect a choice that 
statutory claims would not be heard before three-judge courts.  Congress could 
have  made  no  such  choice  because  in  1976  no  such  choice  existed:  all  such 
apportionment  challenges  were  perforce  constitutional  until  1982,  when 
Congress revised the Voting Rights Act to allow statutory vote dilutions claims. 
See  generally,  Page,  284  F.3d  189-190  (explaining  the  history  of  ยง  2284). 
Chestnut responds that Alabamaโs โclaim that Section 2 was not available for 
reapportionment challenges prior to 1982 seems dubious at best,โ and cites to a 
1980 Fifth Circuit decision in which Section 2 was used to challenge an at-large 
election scheme for a local school board. Doc. 15, p. 8, n.3. This argument misses 
the  mark.  Even  assuming  statutory  vote  dilution  claims  were  possible  before 
Congress amended the Voting Rights Act in 1982, the point remains that in 1976 
when Congress narrowed the scope of ยง 2284, they were unheard of, and 1976, 
not  1982,  is  what  matters  in  determining  Congressional  intent  behind  that 
6 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 8 of 50
statute. The undersigned could not locate a vote dilution case brought under ยง 2 
before 1976, when Congress amended the three-judge court statute. See Ex. B.

believe  that  two  reapportionments  within  a  short 
period  of  two  years  would  greatly  prejudice  the 
County and its citizens by creating instability and 
dislocation in the electoral system and by imposing 
great financial and logistical burdens. 
White, 909 F.2d at 104 (emphasis added). 
  
Moreover, if the Court were to impose redistricting before the 2000 
census, such redistricting would necessarily be based on 1990 census 
20 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 22 of 50
figures.  Such  old  census  figures  have  been  recognized  as  unduly 
prejudicial because they fail to provide a basis for โfair and accurate 
representation for the citizens.โ  
  
Therefore,  the  defendants  have  established  each  of  the  three 
elements necessary to assert the defense of laches. Accordingly, the 
motions to dismiss will be granted as to that issue. 
 
Fouts, 88 F. Supp. 2d at 1354-1355 (quoting and citing White v. Daniel, 909 F.2d 
99 (4th Cir. 1990))(emphasis added in Fouts).  
  Fouts was cited approvingly by the Eleventh Circuit in another redistricting 
case, Sanders v. Dooly County, Ga., 245 F.3d 1289 (11th Cir. 2001). The Sanders 
complaint attacked a joint county commission-board of education redistricting 
plan, but as in this case, the Sanders plaintiffs had waited until two years before 
the next census to file their complaint. On appeal, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed 
the District Courtโs dismissal for laches of plaintiffโs claims for injunctive relief: 
The  district  court  granted  the  defendants  summary  judgment  on 
laches grounds. According to the court, the plaintiffsโ waiting until 
November 1998 to file suitโover six years after the first use of the 
plan and five years after Shaw v. Reno issuedโwas an inexcusable 
delay. This delay prejudiced the defendants and citizens of Dooly 
County, the court concluded, in two principal ways: (1) redistricting 
late  in  the  decade  would  lead  to  back-to-back  redistrictings  (the 
court-ordered one and the one using new census data) that would 
confuse voters and be unnecessarily costly to the County; and (2) the 
census data available to redistrict now are over ten years old and 
thus unreliable. The plaintiffs appeal. 
โฆ. 
 
Turning to the merits, we conclude that the district court did not 
abuse its discretion in deeming the claims seeking injunctive relief to 
be laches-barred for the reasons that we described above. Cf. Fouts 
v.  Harris,  88  F.  Supp.  2d  1351,  1353  (S.D.Fla.1999)  (relying  on 
similar  laches reasoning  to dismiss  Shaw  claims),  affโd sub nom. 
21 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 23 of 50
Chandler v. Harris, 529 U.S. 1084, 120 S.Ct. 1716, 146 L.Ed.2d 639 
(2000). 
 
Sanders, 245 F.3d at 1290-1291.  
 
  However,  the  Eleventh  Circuit  reached  a  different  conclusion  on  the 
plaintiffsโ claim for declaratory relief: 
But we do think that the district court overstepped its discretion in 
judging  the  claims  for  declaratory  relief  to  be  similarly  barred, 
because  the  third  element  of  a  laches  defenseโprejudice  to  the 
defendants  from the unexcused delayโis missing.  โฆ None  of the 
grounds for prejudice that the district court relied on applies to the 
plaintiffsโ claims for a declaration that the 1992 plan violates the 
Equal  Protection  Clause.  There  is  no  risk  of  confusion  from  a 
redistricting, obviously; no burden to the county to redistrict; and no 
use  of  out-of-date  census  data.  An  effect  of  a  grant  of  such 
declaratory  relief  could  be  to  prevent  the  Attorney  General  from 
using the 1993 consent-decree plan as a baseline for retrogression 
analysis in the postโ2000 census round of preclearance proceedings 
under  ยง  5  of  the  Voting  Rights  Act,  but  that  effect  is  no  more 
prejudicial to the defendants now than it would have been in 1993. 
 
Id.,  245  F.3d  at  1291-2192  (footnotes  omitted).  This  part  of  Sanders  is 
distinguishable.  The  specific  benefit  to  plaintiffs  that  the  Eleventh  Circuit 
identified โ resetting the benchmark for purposes of Section 5 review โ is of no 
use to Chestnut. And whether two majority-black districts could have been drawn 
in 2011 is speculative as to whether two such districts will be drawable after the 
2020 Census, particularly if Alabama loses a seat in Congress, leaving the state 
with only six Representatives. 
22 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 19-1   Filed 08/27/18   Page 24 of 50
  Chestnut waited too late to bring her suit, and the defendants and State of 
Alabama  would  be  unduly  prejudiced  if  the  Court  were  to  overlook  her 
inexcusable delay and allow her case to go forward.  
CONCLUSION 
  For  the  reasons  shown  above,  Sen.  McClendon  respectfully  moves  the 
Court to: 
a.  dismiss  the  amended  complaint  for  lack  of  subject-matter 
jurisdiction, or in the alternative certify for interlocutory appeal the 
issue of whether Chestnutโs ยง 2 challenge to the Stateโs congressional 
districts must be heard by a three-judge court, and stay proceedings 
before this Court while the interlocutory appeal is pending; 
 
b. dismiss the amended complaint because Chestnut failed to state a 
claim of vote dilution, or in the alternative certify for interlocutory 
appeal  the  issue  of  whether  Chestnut  must  satisfy  Ginglesโ  first 
threshold requirement in her complaint, and stay proceedings before 
this Court while the interlocutory appeal is pending,  and 
 
c.  dismiss  the  amended  complaint  because  Chestnut  inexcusably 
delayed in commencing this case, and allowing it to proceed would 
unduly prejudice defendants, the State of Alabama, members of the 
Legislature, candidates, and voters.

/s/Dorman Walker

documents.text:
Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 24   Filed 10/16/18   Page 1 of 5 FILED
 
 2018 Oct-16  AM 09:31
U.S. DISTRICT COURT
N.D. OF ALABAMA
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ALABAMA 
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
 
LAKEISHA CHESTNUT, et al.,  ) 
  ) 
  Plaintiffs,  ) 
    ) 
  v.  )  Case No. 2:18-CV-907-KOB 
    )   
JOHN H. MERRILL, in his official  ) 
Capacity as Alabama Secretary of State  ) 
    ) 
  Defendant.  ) 
 
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION AND ORDER 
 
  This matter comes before the court on Alabama Senator Jim McClendonโs โMotion to 
Intervene.โ (Doc. 19). On September 10, this court ordered Plaintiffs to show cause why Senator 
McClendon should not be allowed to intervene as a defendant. On September 10, Defendant 
John Merrill filed โDefendant Secretary of State John Merrillโs Response to Senator Jim 
McClendonโs Motion to Intervene (Doc. 19).โ (Doc. 22). Later that same day, Plaintiffs filed 
โPlaintiffsโ Response to Order to Show Cause and Brief in Opposition to Senator Jim 
McClendonโs Motion to Intervene.โ (Doc. 23). The motion is now ripe for review. 
  Plaintiffs contend that Alabama Act No. 2011-518, now codified at Alabama Code ยง 17-
14-70, caused a discriminatory effect in violation of Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, 52 
U.S.C. ยง 10301. Specifically, Plaintiffs argue that the redistricting of Congressional Districts 1, 
2, 3, and 7 diluted the African-American vote. Senator McClendon was a member of the 
Alabama House of Representatives and the House Chair of the Legislatureโs Permanent 
Committee on Reapportionment when the legislature drew the โ2010 McClendon Congressional 
Districts 1โ plan, which later became Alabama Code ยง 17-14-70. Mr. McClendon seeks to 
1 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 24   Filed 10/16/18   Page 2 of 5
intervene in his official capacity as Alabama Senator and member of Alabama Legislatureโs 
Permanent Legislative Committee on Reapportionment. 
Rule 24(b)(1)(B) 
  Senator McClendon seeks to intervene under Rule 24(b)(1)(B) of the Federal Rules of 
Civil Procedure. Rule 24(b)(1)(B) permits intervention by anyone who โhas a claim or defense 
that shares with the main action a common question of law or fact.โ Senator McClendon 
contends that, as the author of the plan at issue, he is โparticularly well informed to contribute to 
the defense of the Stateโs congressional redistricting plan.โ (Doc. 19 at 4). While the court does 
not doubt Senator McClendonโs knowledge of the plan, he has no claim nor defense in this 
action.  
  Senator McClendon argues that his assistance would be necessary should the court order 
the state to redraw its congressional districts. To begin, such a remedy has not been ordered and 
might never be ordered. To argue that Senator McClendonโs participation in this case is 
necessary because of a potential remedy is highly speculative. More importantly, future 
participation in remedial redistricting is neither a claim nor a defense under Rule 24(b)(1)(B). 
  Senator McClendon also maintains that his help is necessary to protect the interests of the 
Reapportionment Committee and the legislature. But he fails to acknowledge the procedure 
created by the State of Alabama to protect such interests. Alabama Code ยง 36-15-21 provides 
that the state Attorney General controls โ[a]ll litigation concerning the interest of the state, or any 
department of the state.โ Ala. Code ยง 36-15-21 (2018).  
  A proposed intervenorโs interest is presumed adequately represented โwhen an existing 
party pursues the same ultimate objective as the party seeking intervention.โ United States v. 
Georgia, 19 F.3d 1388, 1394 (11th Cir. 1994) (quoting FSLIC v. Falls Chase Special Taxing 
2 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 24   Filed 10/16/18   Page 3 of 5
Dist., 893 F.2d 211, 215 (11th Cir. 1993)). The state Attorney General and Senator McClendon 
seek an identical outcomeโto see the plan upheld as constitutional. Senator McClendon raises 
no argument why the state Attorney Generalโs representation would be inadequate. See One Wis. 
Inst., Inc. v. Nichol, 310 F.R.D. 394, 397 (W.D. Wis. 2015) (โ[T]he attorney general is 
adequately pursuing the outcome that the proposed intervenors seeks. The court is satisfied that 
the existing parties are capable of identifying and presenting the relevant issues in this case.โ).  
  Because the stateโs interest is adequately protected by the Attorney General, Senator 
McClendonโs help is not needed to protect the interests of the legislature and the 
Reapportionment Committee. 
  Senator McClendon has failed to demonstrate why he has a claim or defense in this case 
not already adequately represented by the Attorney General, and so the court must deny his 
motion for intervention under Rule 24(b)(1)(B) 
Rule 24(b)(2) 
  Senator McClendon alternatively seeks to intervene under Rule 24(b)(2). Under 
Rule 24(b)(2), the court may allow โa federal or state governmental officer or agency to 
intervene if a partyโs claim or defense is based on: (A) a statute or executive order administered 
by the officer or agency; or (B) any regulation, order, requirement, or agreement issued or made 
under the statute or executive order.โ Senator McClendon contends that because the Alabama 
Legislature is responsible for drawing congressional districts and defending the Reapportionment 
Committeeโs Guidelines, he should be allowed to intervene. Plaintiffs maintain that Senator 
McClendon is not a state officer administering a statute under Rule 24(b)(2). Instead, they 
correctly argue, the legislature merely promulgates law, but does not enforce or administer the 
law. 
3 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 24   Filed 10/16/18   Page 4 of 5
  The courts have long recognized that state legislators in their official capacities โhave no 
legal interest in the implementation of the laws they pass.โ  Gustafson v. Johns, No. 05-0352-
CG-L, 2005 WL 8158752, at *1 (S.D. Ala. Sept. 30, 2006) (citing Chiles v. Thornburgh, 865 
F.2d 1197, 1205 (11th Cir. 1989)). Rather, โ[l]egislators are not charged with enforcing or 
implementing voting districts.โ Id. (citing Scott v. Taylor, 405 F.3d 1251 (11th Cir. 2005)). 
โClearly, a legislative body promulgates, debates, and passes laws; however, it is not even 
arguable that the legislature administers or enforces those laws.โ General Synod of the United 
Church of Christ v. Resinger, No. 3:14-cv-00213-MOC-DLH, 2014 WL 5094093, at *3 
(W.D.N.C. Oct. 10, 2014). Under Alabama law, the Secretary of State is the proper state entity to 
administer the congressional district plan and state election laws. See Ala. Code ยง 17-1-3(a) 
(2018). So, Senator McClendon is not a state officer administering a statute.  
  Senator McClendon further argues that defending the Reapportionment Committeeโs 
Guidelines and drawing congressional districts are โrequirement[s] . . . issued or made under the 
statute or executive order.โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b)(2)(B). Alabama Code ยง 29-2-52 enumerates the 
various duties of the Committee on Reapportionment, but nowhere indicates a duty to defend or 
uphold the constitutionality of the guidelines or congressional districting plan. Because 
defending the Reapportionment Committeeโs Guidelines was not a requirement issued or made 
under statute, this argument fails.  
  While the statute does require the committee to develop plans for reapportionment, see 
Ala. Code ยง 29-2-52(a)โ(d), Senator McClendon misrepresents Plaintiffsโ claim. Plaintiffs do not 
claim that the legislature intentionally promulgated a racially discriminatory reapportionment 
plan. Such a claim would challenge a requirement under the statute, such as the intent of the 
Reapportionment Committee. Instead, Plaintiffs claim that the plan had a discriminatory effect. 
4 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 24   Filed 10/16/18   Page 5 of 5
An โeffectsโ claim requires no showing of discriminatory intent by the legislature. See Abbott v. 
Perez, 138 S. Ct. 2305, 2330โ31 (2018). Because Plaintiffs are not challenging intent of the 
Reapportionment Committee or legislature, no defense is necessary based on a requirement 
under Alabama Code ยง 29-2-52. 
  Because Senator McClendon failed to demonstrate that either of the government officer 
or agency rule subsections apply to him, therefore, the court must deny his motion to intervene 
under Rule 24(b)(2). 
  For the reasons stated above, the court DENIES Senator McClendonโs motion to 
intervene. 
DONE and ORDERED this 16th day of October, 2018.  
 
 
 
____________________________________ 
KARON OWEN BOWDRE 
CHIEF UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE

FILED
Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 1 of 10
 
 2019 Jan-28  PM 03:51
U.S. DISTRICT COURT
N.D. OF ALABAMA
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ALABAMA 
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
 
LAKEISHA CHESTNUT, et al.,  ) 
  ) 
  Plaintiffs,  ) 
    ) 
  v.  )  Case No. 2:18-CV-00907-KOB 
    )   
JOHN H. MERRILL,  ) 
    ) 
  Defendant.  ) 
 
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION 
 
  This matter comes before the court on Defendantโs โMotion for Judgment on the 
Pleadings.โ (Doc. 27). Defendant first raises jurisdictionโspecifically whether this court must 
refer this case to a three-judge panel pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 2284(a). The court always must 
determine whether it has jurisdiction before proceeding in any case. So, while Defendant raised 
several issues in his motion, the court will only address in this Memorandum Opinion whether it 
lacks jurisdiction and must refer this case to a three-judge panel. 
  Under ยง 2284, as relevant here, a three-judge panel must hear a case if the case either (1) 
raises a constitutional challenge to an apportionment of congressional districts or (2) is 
โotherwise required by Act of Congressโ to be heard by a panel. Plaintiffs allege that the 
Alabama congressional redistricting plan violates Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, 52 U.S.C. 
ยง 10301, but do not allege a constitutional violation. Section 2 does not require challenges 
brought under its authority to be heard by a three-judge panel. 
1 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 2 of 10
  Defendant first raised this jurisdictional question in his โNotice of Jurisdictional Issueโ 
on July 9, 2018.1 (Doc. 12). On November 2, 2018, Defendant filed his โMotion for Judgment on 
the Pleadingsโ in which he contends that this court lacks jurisdiction because a three-judge panel 
must hear this case. (Doc. 27). Plaintiffs filed โPlaintiffsโ Brief in Opposition to Defendantโs 
Motion for Judgment on the Pleadingsโ on November 30, 2018. (Doc. 31). On December 21, 
2018, Defendant filed โSecretary of State John Merrillโs Reply in Support of His Motion for 
Judgment on the Pleadings (Doc. 27).โ (Doc. 37). On January 16, 2019, this court held a motion 
hearing on the issue of whether a three-judge panel must hear this case. (Doc. 35). The 
jurisdictional issue is now ripe for review. 
I.  Background 
  Plaintiffs are eight African-American citizens of Alabama. One Plaintiff resides in 
Congressional District (CD) 1, one resides in CD 2, one resides in CD 3, and five reside in CD 7. 
The redistricting plan currently used in Alabama, Senate Bill 484, allegedly โpacksโ African-
American voters into CD 7. See S.B. 484, 2011 Reg. Sess. (Ala. 2011). The Alabama legislature 
established CD 7 as a majority-minority district following the 1982 Amendments of the Voting 
Rights Act. Nearly one-third of Alabamaโs African-American population falls into CD 7. Prior to 
the passage of S.B. 484, the black voting age population (BVAP) of CD 7 was 58.33%. Now, the 
CD 7 BVAP is 60.91%. Plaintiffs argue that S.B. 484 moved African-American voters from 
predominantly white districts into CD 7 to โpackโ the district designated as a majority-minority 
                                                           
1 Although the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure do not recognize a โnoticeโ as an appropriate 
motion of pleading or filing, and Defendantโs โnoticeโ did not ask the court to take any action, 
the court did evaluate its jurisdiction without formally addressing the issue in writing. Because 
Plaintiffs did not assert a constitutional claim, the undersigned determined that the statutory 
claim did not trigger a three-judge court under ยง 2284. By contrast, Defendantโs motion for 
judgment on the pleadings does ask the court to openly address the jurisdictional question, so the 
court now reviews its jurisdiction for a second time in this Memorandum Opinion. 
2 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 3 of 10
district with African-American voters. The plan also allegedly โcracksโ African-American voters 
in CDs 1, 2, and 3 by splitting among three districts those African-American voters who could be 
grouped together in a second majority-minority district. Plaintiffs contend that the African-
American population in these districts could be united to form a second majority-minority CD. 
  Plaintiffs only raise a Section 2 violation of the Voting Rights Act, alleging vote dilution. 
They do not raise a constitutional challenge to the redistricting plan. 
  Defendant requests a three-judge panel under 28 U.S.C. ยง 2284. Defendant concedes that 
this case does not fall within the express language of ยง 2284โs requirements for a three-judge 
panel. But Defendant argues that Plaintiffs selectively brought only a statutory claim precisely to 
avoid a three-judge panel, and, because the statutory claim is so similar to the corresponding 
constitutional claim Plaintiffs deliberately omitted, a three-judge panel should still hear the case. 
Further, Defendant maintains that the legislative history behind the 1976 amendments to ยง 2284 
and the policies behind ยง 2284 coupled with the Voting Rights Act lean in favor of convening a 
three-judge panel to hear this case. 
  Plaintiffs contend that this case should not go to a three-judge panel because ยง 2284(a) 
plainly states that a three-judge panel shall only be convened when challenging the 
constitutionality of the apportionment of congressional districts or โwhen otherwise required by 
Act of Congress.โ Plaintiffs maintain that โthe plaintiff [is] the master of the claim,โ so the court 
should honor their decision not to bring a constitutional challenge. See Beneficial Natโl Bank v. 
Anderson, 539 U.S. 1, 12 (2003) (Scalia, J., dissenting) (quoting Caterpillar Inc. v. Williams, 482 
U.S. 386, 392 (1987)). Further, Plaintiffs argue that Section 2 does not require a three-judge 
panel, so Section 2 cannot be considered an Act of Congress โotherwiseโ requiring a three-judge 
panel to hear the case. 
3 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 4 of 10
II. Standard of Review 
  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(h)(3) states that โ[i]f the court determines at any time 
that it lacks subject-matter jurisdiction, the court must dismiss the action.โ Indeed, โit is 
incumbent upon [a] federal court[] . . . to constantly examine the basis of jurisdiction, doing so 
on [its] own motion if necessary.โ Save the Bay, Inc. v. U.S. Army, 639 F.2d 1100, 1102 (5th Cir. 
1981) (citing Rule 12(h)(3)); see also Louisville & Nashville R.R. v. Mottley, 211 U.S. 149, 152 
(1908) (โ[I]t is the duty of this court to see to it that the jurisdiction of the circuit court, which is 
defined and limited by statute, is not exceeded.โ). 
III. Discussion 
  Here, the parties do not contest whether a federal court may hear this case, but whether a 
three-judge panel must hear this case. Under 28 U.S.C. ยง 2284(a), โa district court of three 
judges shall be convened when otherwise required by Act of Congress, or when an action is filed 
challenging the constitutionality of the apportionment of congressional districts or the 
apportionment of any statewide legislative body.โ If the court determines that the case must be 
heard by a three-judge panel, โthe judge to whom the request is presented shall . . . immediately 
notify the chief judge of the circuit.โ Id. ยง 2284(b)(1). If a three-judge panel is convened, a single 
judge may not enter a judgment on the merits. Id. ยง 2284(b)(3). So, this court must determine the 
jurisdictional question of whether this case is properly before a single judge before the case can 
continue. 
  On its face, Plaintiffsโ complaint only brings an action under Section 2 of the Voting 
Rights Actโnot under the 14th or 15th Amendments, which often accompany Section 2 causes 
of action; not under any other constitutional provision; and not under any act of Congress that 
โotherwise require[s]โ a three-judge court. 
4 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 5 of 10
  A claim solely alleging a Section 2 violation falls outside a plain reading of ยง 2284. Such 
a claim is neither a constitutional challenge nor โwhen otherwise required by Act of Congress.โ 
A few provisions in the Voting Rights Act require a three-judge panel to hear certain actions. See 
Voting Rights Act of 1965, 52 U.S.C. ยงยง 10303(a)(5), 10304(a) (2012) (requiring a three-judge 
panel to hear Section 4 challenges and Section 5 challenges). But no provision of the Voting 
Rights Act requires a violation of Section 2 to go to a three-judge panel. So, Section 2 of the 
Voting Rights Act cannot be considered โwhen otherwise required by Act of Congressโ within 
ยง 2284(a) to require a three-judge panel for this case. 
  The parties agree that a strict reading of the text of ยง 2284 excludes a Section 2 Voting 
Rights Act challengeโwithout a corresponding constitutional challengeโfrom the requirement 
to be heard by a three-judge panel. 
  Defendant recognizes that Plaintiffsโ complaint only asserts a claim under Section 2 of 
the Voting Rights Act and not a constitutional violation. Defendant also recognizes that in 1976, 
when Congress amended ยง 2284, Congress made the amendments to limit the number of cases 
requiring a three-judge panel. And Defendant recognizes that ยง 2284 plainly reads: โA district 
court of three judges shall be convened when otherwise required by Act of Congress, or when an 
action is filed challenging the constitutionality of the apportionment of the congressional districts 
or the apportionment of any statewide legislative body.โ 
  But Defendant wants this court to read beyond the plain text of the statute. Defendant 
wants this court to read into Section 2 a requirement that such a challenge must go to a three-
judge panel, or to strike โconstitutionalโ from the requirements to invoke a three-judge panel in 
ยง 2284. The court sees no need to go beyond the text of Section 2 or ยง 2284 when their plain 
meanings are so clear.  
5 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 6 of 10
  As the Supreme Court noted long ago, โwhen words are free from doubt they must be 
taken as the final expression of the legislative intent . . . . In other words, the language being 
plain, and not leading to absurd or wholly impracticable consequences, it is the sole evidence of 
the ultimate legislative intent.โ Caminetti v. United States, 242 U.S. 470, 490 (1917). Canons of 
construction cannot be used โto create ambiguity where the statuteโs text and structure suggest 
none.โ Ali v. Fed. Bureau of Prisons, 552 U.S. 214, 227 (2008). Here, the court can find no 
ambiguity on the face of ยง 2284. Because the statute is unambiguous, the court sees no reason to 
go beyond the text. 
  Even assuming the court had free rein to look beyond the text, Defendantโs arguments for 
doing so fail. Defendant contends that the court should read into ยง 2284 congressional intent to 
include Section 2 challenges in addition to constitutional challenges to congressional and 
statewide legislative apportionment plans as matters to be heard by a three-judge panel. To do so, 
Defendant relies on a Justice Scalia quote: โThis canon [of reading a statute fairly] follows 
inevitably from the facts that (1) interpretation always depends on context, (2) context always 
includes evident purpose, and (3) evident purpose always includes effectiveness.โ Antonin Scalia 
& Bryan A. Garner, Reading Law 63 (2012).  
  Defendant argues that โwhen Congress last amended ยง 2284(a), it had no idea that in the 
future there would be a statutory claim for vote dilution.โ (Doc. 37 at 6). Defendant cites to a 
Senate Report from the 1976 amendments to ยง 2284 as evidence that Congress would have 
intended for Section 2 violations to be heard by a three-judge panel. (Id. at 4). The Senate Report 
explains that โ[t]he bill preserves three-judge courts for cases involving congressional 
reapportionment . . . because it is the judgment of the committee that these issues are of such 
importance that they ought to be heard by a three-judge court.โ S. Rep. No. 94-204, at 9 (1976). 
6 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 7 of 10
And, as noted by Defendant in the motion hearing, Congress designed the panel format โto lend 
greater dignity to the proceedings.โ See Michael E. Solimine, The Three-Judge District Court in 
Voting Rights Litigation, 30 U. Mich. J.L. Reform 79, 84 (1996). 
  The court recognizes Defendantโs point that, when Congress amended ยง 2284 in 1976, 
litigators did not yet understand that congressional apportionment plans could be challenged 
under Section 2, and so Congress did not know at that time that ยง 2284 could subsequently be 
used to prevent Section 2 challenges from being heard by three-judge panels. See Page v. 
Bartels, 248 F.3d 175, 189 (3d Cir. 2001) (โ[I]n 1976 . . . ยง 2 of the Voting Rights Act was not 
available to litigants seeking to challenge apportionment. At that time, apportionment challenges 
were generally constitutional in nature.โ). Nevertheless, Congress could have so amended 
Section 2 had it desired to send those cases invoking it to a three-judge court. But currently, 
ยง 2284 and Section 2โreading them together and separatelyโdo not provide three-judge panels 
for purely statutory Section 2 challenges. 
  Congress has reviewed both the statutes since the 1976 amendments of ยง 2284. In 1976, 
Congress amended ยง 2284 to read as it does today. Act of Aug. 12, 1976, Pub. L. No. 94-381, 90 
Stat. 1119. And in 1982, Congress amended the Voting Rights Act so that Section 2 reads as it 
does today. Act of June 29, 1982, Pub. L. 97-205, 96 Stat. 134. That amendment changed the 
numbering of subsections and revised the declaratory judgment proceedings under Section 2, but 
did not amend Section 2 to place cases brought solely under its authority within the โotherwise 
required by Act of Congressโ provision in ยง 2284. In 1984, Congress amended ยง 2284 for a 
second time, but did not change subsection (a). Act of Nov. 9, 1984, Pub. L. No. 98-620, sec. 
402, ยง 29(e), 98 Stat. 3335, 3359.  
7 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 8 of 10
  When Congress amended Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act in 1982, it could have 
amendedโbut did notโthe Voting Rights Act to add a provision directing all Section 2 
challenges to be heard by a three-judge panel. Even beyond 1982, Congress could have amended 
the Voting Rights Act at any point between 1976 and the present to add such a provision. That is, 
Congress could amend the statute to send the case to a three-judge panel โas otherwise required 
by Act of Congressโ pursuant to ยง 2284. 
  Perhaps Defendant forgot that Congress revisited both statutes since the 1976 
amendments to ยง 2284 and could have addressed the subsequent use of Section 2 of whichโ
according to DefendantโCongress โhad no ideaโ in 1976. (Doc. 37 at 6). 
  The court must presume that Congress knows the laws it has enacted. See Cannon v. 
Univ. of Chi., 441 U.S. 677, 696โ97 (1979) (โIt is always appropriate to assume that our elected 
representatives . . . know the law . . . .โ). Indeed, congressional staffers are dedicated to 
researching proposed and current legislation and the effects such legislation may have on other 
statutes. The U.S. House of Representativesโ Office of Legislative Counsel must determine 
โ[w]hat is the relation between the policy [to be legislated] and existing lawโ and โ[m]ust 
existing law be amended to avoid conflicts with the policy[.]โ U.S. House of Representatives, 
Approaching a Problem, OFF. LEGIS. COUNS., http://legcounsel.house.gov/HOLC/
Before_Drafting/Approaching_a_Problem.html (last visited Jan. 16, 2019). Likewise, the 
Senateโs Office of Legislative Counsel makes similar determinations: โA new [legislative] 
measure must be carefully related to earlier enactments to produce, to the maximum extent 
practicable, a consistent body of law that will carry the congressional purpose into effect without 
producing unintended consequences.โ U.S. Senate, Responsibilities of the Legislative Drafter, 
8 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 9 of 10
OFF. LEGIS. COUNS., https://www.slc.senate.gov/Drafting/drafting.htm (last visited Jan. 16, 
2019). 
  The court cannot do Congressโs job. Article I firmly vests all legislative powers to 
Congress. U.S. CONST. art. I, ยง 1. โCongress is presumed to โknow the lawโ and has convened 
many times since a particular statute was enacted or case decided. Because Congress has not 
seen fit to amend [the statute at issue] . . . it remains unchanged, reliable law.โ Wiersum v. U.S. 
Bank, N.A., 785 F.3d 483, 489 n.5 (11th Cir. 2015) (internal citation omitted). If Congress 
wanted to so amend ยง 2284 or Section 2, it could have. But Congress did not. 
  This court intends to remain firmly in its role to apply, not amend, the law. Several cases 
alleging only Section 2 violations have been heard by single judges. See Rural W. Tenn. African-
American Affairs Council v. Sundquist, 290 F.3d 835, 838 (6th Cir. 2000) (noting that the 
underlying case initially alleged both Section 2 and constitutional violations, but โ[b]ecause the 
amended complaint contained no constitutional claims, the three-judge court disbandedโ); see 
also Bone Shirt v. Hazeltine, 336 F. Supp. 2d 976 (D.S.D. 2004); Old Person v. Brown, 182 F. 
Supp. 2d 1002 (D. Mont. 2002). Neither the court nor Defendant could find any purely Section 2 
cases heard by a three-judge panel. So this court will apply the law before it and will not read 
new provisions intoโor strike existing words fromโthe statutes at issue. 
  As Justice Scalia wrote, โContext always matters. Let us not forget, however, why 
context matters: It is a tool for understanding the terms of the law, not an excuse for rewriting 
them.โ King v. Burwell, 135 S. Ct. 2480, 2497 (2015) (Scalia, J., dissenting). The court refuses to 
write into ยง 2284 or into Section 2 a provision requiring complaints alleging Section 2 violations 
to be heard by a three-judge panelโor alternatively striking โconstitutionalโ from ยง 2284โso 
that all apportionment challenges, statutory and constitutional, must be heard by a three-judge 
9 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 40   Filed 01/28/19   Page 10 of 10
panel. If Defendant believes that Congress has made an oversight in amending ยง 2284 or Section 
2โand perhaps requiring Section 2 challenges to be heard by a three-judge panel would make 
senseโhe can raise that issue with the governmental branch charged with drafting and enacting 
the law. This court adheres to the principle that โthe proper role of the judiciary [is] to apply, not 
amend, the work of the Peopleโs representatives.โ Henson v. Santander Consumer USA Inc., 137 
S. Ct. 1718, 1726 (2017) (Gorsuch, J.).  
  This court will apply the law as written. Because Plaintiffsโ complaint raises a challenge 
only under Section 2, which is not a constitutional challenge to an apportionment plan or an act 
of Congress requiring a three-judge panel, the court cannot send this case to a three-judge panel. 
IV. Conclusion 
  For the reasons discussed above and at the hearing on January 16, 2019, the court will 
DENY Defendantโs motion for a judgment on the pleadings as to the jurisdictional issue. (Doc. 
27). This case will remain before this one judge, who will proceed with as much dignity as 
possible and as necessary given the nature of this case. The court will enter a separate Order 
consistent with this Memorandum Opinion. Now that the court has expressed confidence in its 
jurisdiction, the court will move on to separately rule on the remaining issues raised in 
Defendantโs motion for judgment on the pleadings. 
DONE and ORDERED this 28th day of January, 2019.  
 
 
 
____________________________________ 
KARON OWEN BOWDRE 
CHIEF UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE
