FILED
Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 1 of 15
 
 2019 Mar-27  PM 01:10
U.S. DISTRICT COURT
N.D. OF ALABAMA
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF ALABAMA 
SOUTHERN DIVISION 
 
LAKEISHA CHESTNUT, et al.,  ) 
  ) 
  Plaintiffs,  ) 
    ) 
  v.  )  Case No. 2:18-CV-00907-KOB 
    )   
JOHN H. MERRILL, in his official capacity  ) 
as Alabama Secretary of State   ) 
    ) 
  Defendant.  ) 
 
 
MEMORANDUM OPINION 
 
  This matter comes before the court on Defendant John Merrillโs โMotion for Judgment 
on the Pleadingsโ pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(c), filed on November 2, 2018. 
(Doc. 27). In this motion, Defendant raised three grounds for judgment on the pleadings: (1) 
jurisdiction lies with a three-judge court, (2) the complaint fails to demonstrate that a remedy 
exists, and (3) the claims are barred by the doctrine of laches. 
  On November 7, 2018, the court ordered the parties to brief all three issues raised in the 
motion. (Doc. 30). Plaintiffs filed โPlaintiffsโ Brief in Opposition to Defendantโs Motion for 
Judgment on the Pleadingsโ on November 30, 2018. (Doc. 31). On December 21, 2018, 
Defendant filed โSecretary of State John Merrillโs Reply in Support of His Motion for Judgment 
on the Pleadings (Doc. 27).โ (Doc. 37).  
  On January 16, 2019, the court held a hearing solely on the issue of whether jurisdiction 
of this case lay with this court or with a three-judge panel. On January 28, 2019, the court 
entered an Order denying Defendantโs motion for judgment on the pleadings as to the 
jurisdictional issue. (Doc. 41). Because the court has jurisdiction, the case remains before this 
1 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 2 of 15
court. So, the remaining two grounds raised by Defendant in his motion for judgment on the 
pleadings are now ripe for review. 
I.  Background 
  Plaintiffs are eight African-American citizens of Alabama. One Plaintiff resides in 
Congressional District (โCDโ) 1, one resides in CD 2, one resides in CD 3, and five reside in CD 
7. The redistricting plan currently used in Alabama, Senate Bill 484, allegedly โpacksโ African-
American voters into CD 7. See S.B. 484, 2011 Reg. Sess. (Ala. 2011). The Alabama legislature 
established CD 7 as a majority-minority district following the 1982 Amendments of the Voting 
Rights Act. Nearly one-third of Alabamaโs African-American population falls into CD 7.1 Prior 
to the passage of S.B. 484, the black voting age population (BVAP) of CD 7 under the 2002 
redistricting plan was 58.33%. Now, the CD 7 BVAP is 60.91%.  
  Plaintiffs argue that S.B. 484 redrew district lines to โmoveโ African-American voters 
from predominantly white districts into CD 7 to โpackโ the district designated as a majority-
minority district with African-American voters. But the plan also allegedly โcracksโ African-
American voters in CDs 1, 2, and 3 by splitting among three districts those African-American 
voters who could be grouped together in a second majority-minority district. Plaintiffs contend 
that the African-American population in these districts should be united to form a second 
majority-minority CD. 
  Plaintiffs raise a Section 2 violation of the Voting Rights Act, alleging vote dilution. The 
Supreme Court identified three preconditions necessary to establish a vote dilution claim: (1) the 
minority group โis sufficiently large and geographically compact to constitute a majority in the 
single-member district,โ (2) the minority group is โpolitically cohesive,โ and (3) โthe white 
                                                           
1 Based on the facts provided, the court cannot determine whether the CD 7 under the 2011 
redistricting plan is the same CD 7 as drawn following the 1982 Amendments. 
2 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 3 of 15
majority votes sufficiently as a bloc to enable itโin the absence of special circumstances, such 
as the minority candidate running unopposedโusually to defeat the minorityโs preferred 
candidate.โ Thornburg v. Gingles, 478 U.S. 30, 50โ51 (1986) (internal citations omitted). 
II. Standard of Review 
  Rule 12(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allows a party to move for judgment 
on the pleadings after the pleadings are closed, but early enough to not delay trial. See Fed. R. 
Civ. P. 12(c). A judgment on the pleadings is appropriate โwhen there are no material facts in 
dispute, and judgment may be rendered by considering the substance of the pleadings and any 
judicially noticed facts.โ Horsley v. Rivera, 292 F.3d 695, 700 (11th Cir. 2002). To determine 
whether the movant is entitled to a judgment on the pleadings, the court should โaccept as true all 
material facts alleged in the non-moving partyโs pleading, and . . . view those facts in the light 
most favorable to the non-moving party.โ Perez v. Wells Fargo N.A., 774 F.3d 1329, 1335 (11th 
Cir. 2014). 
  The court analyzes a Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings the same way as a 
Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. See 
Dial v. City of Bessemer, No. 2:14-cv-01297-RDP, 2016 WL 3054728, at *3 (N.D. Ala. May 31, 
2016). (โA Rule 12(c) motion for judgment on the pleadings is analyzed the same as a Rule 
12(b)(6) motion to dismiss.โ). โA motion to dismiss and a motion for judgment on the pleadings 
should not be granted unless โthe plaintiff can prove no set of facts in support of his claim which 
would entitle him to relief.โ Losey v. Warden, 521 F. Appโx 717, 719 (11th Cir. 2013) (quoting 
Horsley v. Feldt, 304 F.3d 1225, 1131 (11th Cir. 2002)). So, โto survive a motion for judgment 
on the pleadings, โa complaint must contain sufficient factual matter, accepted as true, to state a 
3 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 4 of 15
claim to relief that it plausible on its face.โโ Id. (quoting Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 
(2009)). 
  To be plausible on its face, the claim must contain enough facts that โallow[] the court to 
draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.โ Iqbal, 556 
U.S. at 678. Although โ[t]he plausibility standard is not akin to a โprobability requirement,โโ the 
complaint must demonstrate โmore than a sheer possibility that a defendant has acted 
unlawfully.โ Id. โWhere a complaint pleads facts that are merely consistent with a defendantโs 
liability, it โstops short of the line between possibility and plausibility of entitlement to relief.โโ 
Id. (quoting Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 557 (2007)). 
  The Supreme Court has identified โtwo working principlesโ for the district court to use in 
applying the facial plausibility standard. The first principle is that, in evaluating motions to 
dismiss, the court must assume the veracity of well-pleaded factual allegations; however, the 
court does not have to accept as true legal conclusions even when โcouched as . . . factual 
allegation[s]โ or โthreadbare recitals of the elements of a cause of action, supported by mere 
conclusory statements.โ Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678. The second principle is that โonly a complaint 
that states a plausible claim for relief survives a motion to dismiss.โ Id. at 679.  
  Thus, under prong one, the court determines the factual allegations that are well-pleaded 
and assumes their veracity, and then proceeds, under prong two, to determine the claimโs 
plausibility given the well-pleaded facts. That task is โcontext-specificโ and, to survive the 
motion, the allegations must permit the court based on its โjudicial experience and common 
sense . . . to infer more than the mere possibility of misconduct.โ Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 679. If the 
court determines that well-pleaded facts, accepted as true, do not state a claim that is plausible, 
the claim must be dismissed. Id. 
4 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 5 of 15
III. Discussion 
Defendant raises two grounds why he is entitled to a judgment on the pleadings: first, 
Plaintiffs failed to demonstrate the existence of a proper remedy; and second, Plaintiffsโ claims 
are barred by the doctrine of laches. The court will discuss each argument in turn. 
a.  Existence of a proper remedy 
Defendant argues that Plaintiffs fail to seek a proper remedy, which causes Plaintiffs to 
lack standing. If a party cannot show that the injury can be redressed by the litigation, then the 
party lacks standing. See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560โ61 (1992) 
(identifying the three elements of standing: injury-in-fact, causality, and redressability). 
The Eleventh Circuit has held that a plaintiff must demonstrate a viable remedy to 
properly allege a Section 2 violation of the Voting Rights Act. See Nipper v. Smith, 39 F.3d 
1494, 1530โ31 (11th Cir. 1994) (โA district court must determine as part of the Gingles 
threshold inquiry whether it can fashion a permissible remedy in the particular context of the 
challenged system.โ). Specifically, where a plaintiff seeks redistricting to create a new majority-
minority district, the plaintiff must demonstrate that the โminority voters possess the potential to 
elect representatives in the absence of the challenged structure or practice.โ Thornburg, 478 U.S. 
at 57 n.17. 
Plaintiffs alleged in the complaint that โ[t]he African-American population in Alabama is 
sufficiently numerous and geographically compact to form a majority of eligible votersโ
meaning a majority of the voting age populationโin two congressional districts.โ (Doc. 14 at 2). 
Specifically, they seek the adoption of a new congressional redistricting plan that adds a second 
majority-minority district in Alabama. (Id. at 29โ30). 
5 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 6 of 15
Defendant argues that Plaintiffs offered these conclusory allegations without factual 
support. But Plaintiffs support each assertion with statistical and anecdotal evidence. Plaintiffs 
point out that CDs 1, 2, and 3 each have a heavily African-American area within a majority-
white district. (Doc. 14 at 12). Plaintiffs explain in their complaint how โAfrican-American 
voters in Alabama are politically cohesive and overwhelmingly support[] Democratic 
candidates,โ with several statistical examples from Alabama elections in the CDs at issue. (Id. at 
13). In contrast, โ[t]he white majority . . . overwhelmingly supports Republican candidates.โ 
(Id.). Defendantโs argument attacking the complaint as โconclusoryโ seems as though he has not 
read past the first page of the complaint because the complaint as a whole contains the support 
and explanation for the initial conclusory statements. 
Plaintiffs argue that Defendant conflates the requirements for pleading with the 
requirements for proving. While Defendant is correct that Plaintiffs must eventually prove that a 
new redistricting plan would resolve the alleged Section 2 violation, such proof is not necessary 
at the pleading stage. Courts hesitate to require a plaintiff to prove the elements of a claim at the 
motion to dismiss stage. โAsking for plausible grounds to infer [an element of a claim] does not 
impose a probability requirement at the pleading stage; it simply calls for enough fact to raise a 
reasonable expectation that discovery will reveal evidence of [the claim].โ Twombly, 550 U.S. at 
556. And โ[i]t is no accident that most cases under section 2 have been decided on summary 
judgment or after a verdict, and not on a motion to dismiss.โ Metts v. Murphy, 363 F.3d 8, 11 
(1st Cir. 2004) (holding that the district court was too quick to dismiss the case because โthe 
plaintiffs are entitled to an opportunity to develop evidence before the merits are resolvedโ). 
Defendant further argues that one unreported district court case indicates that a plaintiff 
must submit a map presenting an alternative redistricting plan to satisfy the potential remedy 
6 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 7 of 15
requirement. See Broward Citizens for Fair Districts v. Broward Cty., No. 12-60317-CIV, 2012 
WL 1110053, at *5 n.6 (N.D. Fla. Apr. 3, 2012) (โThe Court agrees that this [failure to present 
alternative maps] represents an additional pleading deficiency in Plaintiffsโ Amended 
Complaint.โ). But another district court specifically refused to follow Broward Citizens, noting 
that in Broward Citizens โthat court extended what is an evidentiary requirement for purposes of 
summary judgment to the pleading stage of litigation.โ Luna v. Cty. of Kern, No. 1:16-cv-00568-
DAD-JLT, 2016 WL 4679723, at *5 (E.D. Cal. Sept. 2, 2016). The District Court for the Eastern 
District of California noted that โ[f]orcing plaintiffs to develop an unobjectionable map, before 
discovery even begins, would be putting the cart before the horse.โ Id. This court agrees. 
To satisfy the pleading requirements, Plaintiffs only must allege with โenough fact to 
raise a reasonable expectation that discovery will reveal evidenceโ that a second majority-
minority district exists. Twombly, 550 U.S. at 556. In Luna, the court found that such a district 
plausibly existed when the plaintiffs alleged that the Latino population in Kern County grew 
from 25% to 34%. Luna, 2016 WL 4679723, at *4. The court inferred from those statistics that 
โa minority group compromising nearly one-third of the countyโs total voting population could 
comprise majorities in each of at least two county supervisorial districts.โ Id. 
Likewise in our case, Plaintiffs allege that the three allegedly โcrackedโ CDs contain four 
counties with large minority populations: Macon County in CD 3, 82.6% African-American 
population; Mobile County in CD 1, 34.6% African-American population; Monroe County in 
CD 1, 34.6% African-American population; and Montgomery County in CDs 2,3, and 7, 54.7% 
African-American population. (Doc. 31 at 16). Plaintiffs also explain how the area known as the 
7 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 8 of 15
โBlack Beltโ2 was specifically divided between the four CDs at issue in the complaint, packing 
minorities into CD 7 and cracking CDs 1, 2, and 3. (Id.). From this division of the Black Belt, the 
court can infer that a second majority-minority district could plausibly be formed. 
So, while Plaintiffs have not yet proven by presenting an alternative district map that an 
alternative redistricting plan that resolves the alleged Section 2 violations definitely exists, they 
have met the burden to plead Section 2 violations by showing that such a plan plausibly could 
exist. Because such a plan plausibly exists, the court must deny Defendantโs motion for judgment 
on the pleadings on the grounds of standing. 
b.  Doctrine of laches 
  Defendant also argues that Plaintiffsโ claim is barred by the doctrine of laches. 
Specifically, Defendant contends that Plaintiffsโ claims first became available in June 2011 when 
the redistricting plan was passed; that Plaintiffs had no excuse for delay because the 2010 Census 
data upon which their claim is based was available since February 2011; and that the state of 
Alabama would be prejudiced because a final decision (after appeal) would not be reached until 
2019 or 2020, requiring a new redistricting plan to be drawn based on outdated census 
information from 2010โand shortly before statewide redistricting using the 2020 Censusโif 
Plaintiffs succeed. 
  Preliminarily, Plaintiffs contend that the doctrine of laches only applies in cases seeking 
retrospective damages. See Peter Letterese & Assocs., Inc. v. World Inst. of Scientology Enters., 
                                                           
2 The โBlack Beltโ is so named โbecause the soil in that region of the state is dark in color. 
Additionally, during the period immediately following the Civil War, the majority population in 
that area of the state was black.โ Knight v. Alabama, 787 F. Supp. 1030, 1067 n.13 (N.D. Ala. 
1991); see also Zachary L. Guyse, Note, Alabamaโs Original Sin: Property Taxes, Racism, and 
Constitutional Reform in Alabama, 65 Ala. L. Rev. 519, 532 (2013) (โThe name โBlack Beltโ is 
primarily derived from the dark, rich layer of topsoil that runs across the width of roughly twelve 
counties in central Alabama, which made the region extremely fertile for cotton farming.โ). 
8 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 9 of 15
533 F.3d 1287, 1321 (11th Cir. 2008) (โ[L]aches serves as a bar only to the recovery of 
retrospective damages, not to prospective relief.โ). Here Plaintiffs seek no retrospective 
damages, solely prospective relief. But, as Defendant points out, redistricting challenges are 
subject to the doctrine of laches because of the ten-year expiration date of electoral districts. See 
Sanders v. Dooly Cty., 245 F.3d 1289, 1290โ91 (11th Cir. 2001) (per curiam) (applying the 
doctrine of laches to a voting rights case). Electoral districts expire every ten years because the 
federal government conducts a new census every ten years, which the state then uses to create an 
updated redistricting plan. See 2020 Census: What is the Census?, U.S. Census Bureau, 
https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/2020-census/about.html (last visited 
Mar. 11, 2019). 
  So, because the doctrine of laches can apply to redistricting cases, the court will address 
the elements of the doctrine. The doctrine of laches requires three elements: โ(1) a delay in 
asserting a right or a claim; (2) that the delay was not excusable; and (3) that there was undue 
prejudice to the party against whom the claim is asserted.โ Venus Lines Agency Inc. v. CVG Intโl 
Am., Inc., 234 F.3d 1225, 1230 (11th Cir. 2000) (quoting Kason Indus., Inc. v. Component 
Hardware Grp., Inc., 120 F.3d 1199, 1203 (11th Cir. 1997)). Each element will be discussed in 
turn. 
i.  Delay in asserting a right or claim 
  Defendant asserts that Plaintiffs delayed in challenging the redistricting plan because the 
claim became available in June 2011, when Alabamaโs redistricting plan went into effect, and 
because the 2010 Census, which Plaintiffs use to support their arguments for redistricting, was 
already available to Plaintiffs in June 2011. Further, Defendant contends that Plaintiffs did not 
9 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 10 of 15
challenge the past four elections in 2012, 2014, 2016, and 2016, but instead waited until just 
before the government conducts the 2020 Census. 
  Defendant suggests that, because Plaintiffs could have filed suit seven years prior, the 
claim is inexcusably delayed. One court has found inexcusable delay when the challenged 
redistricting plan was no longer the plan used. See White v. Daniel, 909 F.2d 99, 102โ03 (4th 
Cir. 1990) (finding that the plaintiffs delayed by challenging the 1981 planโwhich was just a 
continuation of the 1971 plan with no changesโwhen plaintiffs never challenged the 1971 plan 
and waited until after the last election under the 1981 plan to file suit). A different court found 
inexcusable delay when only one election under the challenged plan remained, and four elections 
based on that plan had passed. See Fouts v. Harris, 88 F. Supp. 2d 1351, 1354 (S.D. Fla. 1999), 
affโd sub nom. Chandler v. Harris, 529 U.S. 1084 (2000). 
  Nine of the Plaintiffs were registered voters in Alabama in June 2011.3 Those nine 
citizens delayed in bringing their case, but was the delay excusable? And Ms. Chestnut, the one 
Plaintiff not residing in Alabama in June 2011, has been a registered voter in Alabama since 
2016. (Doc. 31 at 23). Even though she did not live in Alabama when the redistricting plan first 
came into effect, she has had two years to bring such a claim. 
  But Plaintiffs also argue that the claim did not necessarily arise in 2011, which leads to 
the second element of the doctrine of laches. 
ii.  Delay was not excusable 
  Delay is โmeasured from the time at which the plaintiff knows or should know she has a 
provable claim.โ Kason Indus., Inc., 120 F.3d at 1206. Plaintiffs argue that, at the time the 2011 
                                                           
3 While Plaintiffs do not allege that all nine of them were in fact registered to vote in June 2011, 
the court presumes this to be true because Plaintiffs only argue that Ms. Chestnut could not have 
brought her case any sooner because she did not live in Alabama until 2016. (Doc. 31 at 22). 
10 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 11 of 15
redistricting plan was passed, they were not immediately aware that their votes would be diluted. 
Additionally, Ms. Chestnut, did not reside is Alabama until 2016, so she could not have sued 
earlier.  
  The Eleventh Circuit has recognized that โa plaintiffโs reasonable need to fully 
investigate its claimsโ may excuse delay. Black Warrior Riverkeeper, Inc. v. U.S. Army Corps of 
Engโrs, 781 F.3d 1271, 1285 (11th Cir. 2015). But even if the nine Plaintiffs who were citizens 
in 2011 did not realize their claim arose in June 2011, they were registered voters in Alabama for 
the next three election cycles before bringing a claim. Plaintiffs suggest that Ms. Chestnut could 
have reasonably taken until 2018 to investigate her claims, although they do not explain why the 
other plaintiffs would be justified in a seven-year delay from the 2011 redistricting. And 
Plaintiffs provide no demonstration of the steps taken to investigate the claim that would justify 
the delay.  
  As to Ms. Chestnut, one plaintiffโs delay does not necessarily prejudice others. For 
example, a political partyโs sophisticated knowledge of a stateโs election laws and awareness of a 
claim is not imputed to ordinary citizens Nader 2000 Primary Comm., Inc. v. Hechler, 112 F. 
Supp. 2d, 575, 579 n.2 (S.D. W. Va. 2000). But our case does not involve one sophisticated 
plaintiffโs greater knowledge being imputed to ordinary citizens. Instead, our case involves nine 
citizensโwho supposedly had been investigating their claims since they arose in June 2011โ
joined by a new citizen, who then needed an additional two years after moving into the state to 
join the other nine in bringing this claim. The court finds these excuses for the delay 
unpersuasive. 
11 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 12 of 15
iii. Defendant was prejudiced 
  Defendant argues that the state of Alabama would be prejudiced because, if Plaintiffs 
win, a new redistricting plan must be drawn using 2010 Census data merely a year or two before 
the new 2020 Census; Defendant points to demographic shifts in Alabama since the 2010 
Census, implying that the redistricting plan will have to change in 2021. (Doc. 27 at 18). 
Defendant also contends that redistricting now would spend valuable state resources that could 
otherwise be allocated to the 2021 redistricting plan, while noting that Alabama may lose a 
congressional seat following the 2020 Census. 
  In support, Defendant cites the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, 
which held that forcing the state to redistrict when one election remained under the challenged 
plan โwould come at great cost and yield results that are at best uncertain, and at worst, 
perverse.โ MacGovern v. Connolly, 637 F. Supp. 111, 116 (D. Mass. 1986). But at the time of 
that case, the 1985 Census was not yet complete, and the state was already in the process of 
redistricting. The court noted, โSince the 1985 census may not be complete, an injunction at this 
point could have the ironic effect of forcing a hasty reapportionment based on the already-
superseded 1975 state census . . . .โ Id. In our case, redistricting will certainly be costly. But the 
2010 Census still remains the most current data available as of today. 
  Defendant also cites Fouts, in which the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of 
Florida found that forcing the state to redistrict two years before the mandatory redistricting 
would โresult[] in voter confusion, instability, dislocation, and [a] financial and logistical burden 
on the state.โ Fouts, 88 F. Supp. 2d at 1354. But as noted by Plaintiffs, โredistricting to remedy a 
ยง 2 violation will always require the allocation of some voters to different districts.โ (Doc. 31 at 
30). Plaintiffs also point out that a court has previously ordered redistricting within two years of 
12 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 13 of 15
another redistricting. See Larios v. Cox, 300 F. Supp. 2d 1320 (N.D. Ga. 2004), affโd, 542 U.S. 
947 (2004) (finding that the 2002 reapportionment plan was unconstitutional, and ordering 
redistricting in 2004). But the court notes that the plaintiffs in this case seek a new 
reapportionment plan two years before the next scheduled reapportionment plan, while the 
plaintiffs in Larios sought a new reapportionment plan two years after the last reapportionment 
plan. So Larios does not provide support for Plaintiffsโ position. 
  Further, Defendant cites Sanders in support of his argument that Plaintiffsโ delay 
prejudiced him. In Sanders, voters in Dooly County, Georgia sued county officials, alleging that 
the county commission and board of education districting plan contained racially gerrymandered 
districts in violation of equal protection. 245 F.3d at 1290. The plaintiffs waited five years after 
the plan was released to sue. Id. The Eleventh Circuit ruled that the U.S. District Court did not 
abuse its discretion by ruling that the plaintiffsโ claims for injunctive relief were barred by 
laches. Id. at 1291. But the Eleventh Circuit did not independently evaluate whether the delay 
actually prejudiced the defendants. The district court concluded that the delay prejudiced the 
defendants because (1) the back-to-back redistrictings would cause confusion and expense, and 
(2) the census data available was โover 10 years old and thus unreliable.โ Id. at 1290โ91.  
  But this case differs from Sanders. As Plaintiffs point out, the congressional redistricting 
here would likely be less confusing than the localized county redistricting in Sanders. 
Congressional races are better funded and highly publicized, so voters would be more aware of 
which district they belong. (Doc. 31 at 30). And the 2010 Census data available here, while nine 
years old, is more reliable than the 10 year old data in Sanders because the government has not 
yet taken a new census. See 2020 Census: What is the Census?, U.S. Census Bureau, 
https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/decennial-census/2020-census/about.html (last visited 
13 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 14 of 15
Mar. 11, 2019) (explaining that the federal government took the first census in 1790 โand our 
country has every 10 years sinceโ).  
  While the data available in this case is nine years old, it remains the most up-to-date 
information availableโuntil the government completes the 2020 Census. The U.S. District Court 
for the Southern District of Florida held that ordering a state to redistrict in 1999 forced the state 
to use the 1990 Census data, and โ[s]uch old census figures have been recognized as unduly 
prejudicial because they fail to provide a basis for โfair and accurate representation to the 
citizens.โโ Fouts, 88 F. Supp. 2d at 1354 (quoting White, 909 F.2d at 104). And while 
congressional races are better funded and more highly publicized, the court remains unconvinced 
that a more publicized election will necessarily educate voters on where the newly drawn district 
lines lay. As noted by the Fourth Circuit, โtwo reapportionments within a short period of two 
years would greatly prejudice the [state] and its citizens by creating instability and dislocation in 
the electoral system and by imposing great financial and logistical burdens.โ White, 909 F.2d at 
104. 
  The court finds that to force the state of Alabama to redistrict twice in two yearsโonce 
based on nine-year-old census dataโwould result in prejudice. This prejudice was caused by 
Plaintiffsโ inexcusable delay in waiting until 2018 to file suit. So, the doctrine of laches bars 
Plaintiffsโ claim to the extent Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief. 
  But, in addition to injunctive relief, Plaintiffs seek declaratory relief. Redistricting 
committees sometimes base new redistricting plans on existing plans. The Eleventh Circuit has 
held that, while the defendant may be prejudiced by the plaintiffโs delay in bringing a voting 
rights claim for injunctive relief, the same prejudice does not apply to a claim for declaratory 
relief. See Sanders, 245 F.3d at 1291โ92. Finding the current plan unconstitutionalโif it isโ
14 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 52   Filed 03/27/19   Page 15 of 15
would prevent the committee from reusing the plan as the basis for the 2021 redistricting plan. 
See id. at 1291 (noting that declaratory relief in a voting rights case may โprevent the Attorney 
General from using the [challenged] plan as a baseline for retrogression analysis in the [new] 
census round of preclearance proceedingsโ). Even if the court were to find that Defendant would 
be prejudiced as to injunctive relief, declaratory relief would still be available to Plaintiffs. 
  Because Defendant cannot demonstrate prejudice as to Plaintiffsโ claim for declaratory 
relief, the doctrine of laches will not bar declaratory relief. So, Plaintiffsโ claim will remain as to 
declaratory relief. 
IV. Conclusion 
  For the reasons discussed above, the court will GRANT IN PART and DENY IN PART 
Defendant John Merrillโs motion for judgment on the pleadings. The court will DENY 
Defendantโs motion as to the standing issue. The court will GRANT Defendantโs motion as to 
the doctrine of laches issue for injunctive relief. The court will DENY Defendantโs motion as to 
the doctrine of laches issue for declaratory relief. The court will enter a separate Order consistent 
with this Memorandum Opinion. 
DONE and ORDERED this 27th day of March, 2019.  
 
 
 
____________________________________ 
KARON OWEN BOWDRE 
CHIEF UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE

I.  Introduction 
This lawsuit challenges Alabamaโs 2011 congressional districting plan (the 
โ2011 Planโ) for failing to provide African Americans an equal opportunity to 
participate in the political process and elect their preferred candidates. Though 
African  Americans  comprise  more  than  a  quarter  of  Alabamaโs  voting  age 
population,  their  voting  strength  is  confined  to  just  one  of  the  Stateโs  seven 
congressional districts. 
At trial, Plaintiffs will prove that the African-American community in central 
and  southern  Alabama  is  sufficiently  numerous  and  geographically  compact  to 
constitute a majority of the voting age population in two congressional districts. 
Despite this, the 2011 Plan packs most African Americans in this region into the 
Stateโs  single  pre-existing  majority-minority  district  and  divides  the  remaining 
African-American  population  among  three  districts  in  which  they  comprise  an 
ineffectual political minority.  
African-American voters in Congressional District (โCDโ) 7, the Stateโs sole 
majority-minority  district,  have  consistently  enjoyed  overwhelming  electoral 
success in congressional elections. From 2002 through 2010, African-American-
preferred candidates won CD 7 by margins of more than 45 percentage points. 
Despite this fact, the 2011 Plan increased the African-American population in CD 7 
by  almost  an  additional  percentage  point  and  further  splintered  the  remaining 
 
- 1 - 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 102   Filed 10/28/19   Page 9 of 46
 
African-American communitiesโlocated predominantly in the Stateโs Black Belt 
regionโamong CDs 1, 2, and 3. Indeed, the African-American population alone in 
CDs 1, 2, and 3 constitutes over 90% of the population of a full congressional 
district. Instead of concentrating African-American voters in CD 7 and dispersing 
others across the surrounding districts, the 2011 Plan couldโand shouldโinclude a 
second majority-minority congressional district in the Black Belt region.  
Plaintiffs challenge the 2011 Plan under Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act 
(โVRAโ),  which  prohibits  district  plans  that  dilute  a  minority  groupโs  voting 
strength. Section 2 calls for a two-step inquiry to determine whether Plaintiffs lack 
โan equal opportunity to participate in the political processes and to elect candidates 
of their choice.โ Thornburg v. Gingles, 478 U.S. 30, 46 (1986). The first phase, the 
โGingles preconditions,โ examines whether it is possible to create an additional 
majority-minority district and whether voting in the region is racially polarized. As 
the facts above suggest, the evidence at trial will easily satisfy these requirements. 
The second phase of the analysis examines the past and present realities of 
Alabama politics through a series of factors, which together show that Alabamaโs 
failure to create a second majority-African-American congressional district denies 
African Americans equal footing in congressional elections. The facts and evidence 
relevant to these considerationsโincluding Alabamaโs sordid history of voting-
 
- 2 - 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 102   Filed 10/28/19   Page 10 of 46
 
related discrimination, the effects borne of discrimination across sectors, and the 
absence  of  African-American  elected  officials  in  statewide  officeโare  largely 
beyond  dispute.  As  a  result,  the  evidence  at  trial  will  confirm  that  Alabamaโs 
congressional map violates the VRA. 
II.  Legal Framework of a Vote Dilution Claim Under Section 2 
  
The VRA is one of this nationโs seminal pieces of civil rights legislation. 
Section 2 of the VRA, under which Plaintiffs bring this suit, makes unlawful any 
law that โresults in a denial or abridgement of the right of any citizen of the United 
States to vote on account of race or color.โ 52 U.S.C. ยง 10301(a). In 1982, Congress 
amended Section 2 to reject the Supreme Courtโs โplurality opinion in Mobile v. 
Bolden,  446  U.S.  55  (1980),  which  had  declared  that,  in  order  to  establish  a 
violation[,] . . . minority voters must prove that a contested electoral mechanism was 
intentionally adopted or maintained by state officials for a discriminatory purpose.โ 
Gingles, 478 U.S. at 35. Today, โ[a] discriminatory result is all that is requiredโ to 
establish a Section 2 claim; โdiscriminatory intent is not necessary.โ Ga. State Conf. 
of NAACP v. Fayette Cty. Bd. of Commโrs, 775 F.3d 1336, 1342 (11th Cir. 2015).  
A voting law dilutes minority voting strength in violation of Section 2 if, under 
the totality of the circumstances, the โpolitical processes leading to nomination or 
election in the State . . . are not equally open to participation by members of [a racial 
 
- 3 - 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 102   Filed 10/28/19   Page 11 of 46
 
minority group] . . . in that its members have less opportunity than other members 
of the electorate to participate in the political process and to elect representatives of 
their  choice.โ  52  U.S.C.  ยง 10301(b).  The  โessenceโ  of  this  claim  is  that  the 
challenged  law  โinteracts  with  social  conditions  to  cause  an  inequality  in  the 
opportunities enjoyed by black and white voters to elect their preferred candidates.โ 
Gingles,  478  U.S.  at  47.  In  the  context  of  a  single-member  districting  plan, 
โโ[d]ilution of racial minority group voting strength may be causedโ either โby the 
dispersal of blacks into districts in which they constitute an ineffective minority of 
voters or from the concentration of blacks into districts where they constitute an 
excessive  majority.โโ  Voinovich  v.  Quilter,  507  U.S.  146,  154  (1993)  (quoting 
Gingles, 478 U.S. at 46 n.11). Alabamaโs current congressional map commits both 
forms of dilution: it packs African-American voters into CD 7, and it divides the 
remaining African-American population in the area between CDs 1, 2, and 3. 
The legal analysis under Section 2 follows two steps. First, to make a prima 
facie case under Section 2 a plaintiff must establish three preconditions: (1) the 
minority group is โsufficiently large and geographically compact to constitute a

community.โ Id. at 1524โ26 & nn.60, 64 (emphasis added); Fayette Cty., 950 F. 
Supp. 2d at 1321 (when โPlaintiffs have proved the Gingles factors, it is up to 
the . . . Defendant[] to rebut Plaintiffsโ proof of vote dilutionโ). That is no small feat, 
as โproof of the second and third Gingles factors will ordinarily create a sufficient 
inference that racial bias is at work.โ Nipper, 39 F.3d at 1525. In fact, the Eleventh 
Circuit has stated that โ[t]he surest indication of race-conscious politics is a pattern 
of racially polarized voting.โ Marengo Cty., 731 F.2d at 1567.  
 
- 35 - 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 102   Filed 10/28/19   Page 43 of 46
 
D.  Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act 
Defendant will erroneously seek refuge in Section 5 of the VRA by arguing 
that  in  adopting  the  2011  Plan,  Alabama  legislators  were  concerned  that  a 
congressional  plan  with  two  majority-minority  districts  would  not  have  been 
precleared. At the time the 2011 Plan was adopted, Alabama was subject to Section 
5โs preclearance regime, which would have prohibited the State from enacting a 
congressional plan with โthe effect of diminishing the ability of [African Americans] 
to elect their preferred candidates of choice.โ 52 U.S.C. ยง 10304(b).  
As an initial matter, Section 5โs anti-retrogression principle cannot serve as a 
defense to Plaintiffsโ claim. Because Plaintiffs are asserting an effects-based Section 
2 claim, the intent of those who drew the 2011 Plan is completely irrelevant. Fayette 
Cty., 775 F.3d at 1342. Thus, it makes no difference whether those who drew the 
2011 Plan were concernedโcorrectly or incorrectlyโthat a plan with two majority-
minority districts might not have passed preclearance. The good faith intent of the 
mapdrawers does not inoculate a claim under Section 2โs results test. 
But even if Section 5 could serve as a defense to a Section 2 claim, the 
evidence at trial will demonstrate that Section 5 posed no obstacle to Alabama 
enacting a congressional plan with two majority-minority districts. As Dr. Palmerโs 
functionality analysis demonstrates, the creation of an additional majority-minority 
district would have expandedโnot diminishedโAfrican Americansโ opportunities 
 
- 36 - 

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB   Document 102   Filed 10/28/19   Page 44 of 46
 
to elect their preferred candidates. SF ยถ 164; PX080 ยถยถ 8, 11. 
For the same reason, Alabamaโs choice to increase CD 7โs BVAP in the 2011 
Plan from what it was in the 2001 Plan cannot be explained as an attempt to avoid 
retrogression. Between 2002 and 2010, African-American-preferred candidates won 
CD 7 by over 45 percentage points. PX087โ091. Alabama did not need to maintain, 
let alone increase, the BVAP in CD 7 to ensure that African Americans in that district 
would continue to elect their candidates of choice. Ala. Legislative Black Caucus v. 
Alabama, 135 S. Ct. 1257, 1272 (2015) (โSection 5 . . . does not require a covered 
jurisdiction to maintain a particular numerical minority percentage.โ); id. at 1273 
(criticizing Alabamaโs โmechanically numerical view as to what counts as forbidden 
retrogressionโ). โNonretrogression is not a license for the State to do whatever it 
deems necessary to ensure continued electoral success; it merely mandates that the 
minorityโs opportunity to elect representatives of its choice  not be diminished, 
directly or indirectly, by the Stateโs actions.โ Bush v. Vera, 517 U.S. 952, 982โ83 
(1996). Alabamaโs choice in 2011 to increase the concentration of African-American 
voters in CD 7 thus had no connection to Section 5โs anti-retrogression requirement. 
V.  Conclusion 
The evidence at trial will demonstrate that the 2011 Plan dilutes the voting 
strength of African-American Alabamians in violation of Section 2 of the VRA.

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 5 of 31
 
I.  Introduction 
  The vast majority of the evidence that Plaintiffs offered at trial in this case 
went unanswered. Instead of defending this case on the merits, Defendant offered 
irrelevant  and  legally  unsupported  arguments  that,  if  adopted,  would  radically 
transform the well-settled framework governing Section 2 of  the Voting Rights Act 
(โVRAโ). First, Defendantโs position that the Court should consider the legislative 
history behind the 2011 congressional plan (โ2011 Planโ) when determining whether 
it currently dilutes minority voting strength fundamentally misunderstands how an 
effects-based claim operates under Section 2. Second, Defendantโs attempt to import 
the racial gerrymandering doctrine into the context of a Section 2 claim has been 
thoroughly rejected by the Eleventh Circuit. Third, Defendantโs assertion that the 
vote dilution that results from the 2011 Plan can be dismissed as โpolitics as usualโ 
ignores both the legal standard and the role that race plays in Alabamaโs politics. 
  The evidence presented at trial that was actually relevant to Section 2 made a 
clear case of unlawful vote dilution. With respect to the Gingles preconditions, 
Plaintiffs proved that (1) two majority-African-American congressional districts can 
be drawn in central and southern Alabama, each containing a reasonably compact 
African-American  population,  (2)  African-American  voters  in  that  area  vote 
cohesively, and (3) white voters in the area vote as a bloc usually to defeat the 
 
- 1 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 6 of 31
 
candidate preferred by African Americans. The totality of the circumstances of 
Alabamaโs politicsโand the undersized role African Americans play within itโ
confirms  that  African  Americans  do  not  enjoy  an  equal  opportunity  to  elect 
candidates of their choice in Alabamaโs congressional elections.1 
II.  Defendantโs arguments, if adopted, would fundamentally alter Section 2. 
  
A.  The legislative history behind the current congressional plan is 
irrelevant to whether it currently results in unlawful vote dilution. 
The question before this Court, and any court addressing a Section 2 effects 
claim, is not what the State could have or should have done when the challenged 
plan was passed. Rather, it is whether the  plan โoperates today to exclude [a minority 
group] from a fair chance to participateโ in the relevant political system. Nipper v. 
Smith, 39 F.3d 1494, 1521-22 (11th Cir. 1994) (en banc) (plurality opinion of Tjoflat, 
C.J.) (emphasis added) (quoting S. Rep. No. 97-417 at 36 (1982)). As Plaintiffs 
maintained at trial, 1 Tr. 174:9-18; 3 Tr. 621:12-23; 4 Tr. 806:22, the process of 
enacting the planโi.e., the plans that were submitted to and considered by the 
Legislature, hearsay statements from congressional representatives, or the intent of 
the legislators who passed the planโis irrelevant.  
                                                 
1 This brief highlights evidence and arguments not already discussed in Plaintiffsโ 
Pre-Trial Brief. Plaintiffs thus incorporate their Pre-Trial Brief by reference. ECF 
No. 102 (โPls.โ Br.โ). 
 
- 2 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 7 of 31
 
In  1982,  Congress  created  an  effects-based  claim  within  Section  2  as  a 
response to Mobile v. Bolden, 446 U.S. 55 (1980), which โrequired proof of what 
was in the minds of legislators who enacted or retained a voting law alleged to be 
discriminatory.โ Solomon v. Liberty Cty., Fl., 899 F.2d 1012, 1026-27 (11th Cir. 
1990). Unlike the claim envisioned in Bolden, this effects-based claim asks only 
โwhether[,] as a result of the challengedโ map, Plaintiffs currently lack โan equal 
opportunity to participate in the political processes and to elect candidates of their 
choice.โ Gingles, 478 U.S. at 44. The reasons the plan was adopted are irrelevant. 
Shaw v. Reno, 509 U.S. 630, 641 (1993) (explaining that Section 2 โprohibit[s] 
legislation  that  results  in  the  dilution  of  a  minority  groupโs  voting  strength, 
regardless of the legislatureโs intentโ); Hall v. Louisiana, 108 F. Supp. 3d 419, 425 
(M.D. La. 2015) (โ[The] โresults testโ of Section 2 . . . focuses on objective facets of 
the local political context instead of probing the minds of legislators.โ).  
Defendantโs assertion that Plaintiffsโ claim should fail because, among other 
reasons, Representative Sewell allegedly supported passage of the 2011 Plan or 
because only certain plans were proposed to the Committee, thus ignores that โa 
discriminatory result is all that is requiredโ to prevail under Section 2. Ga. State 
Conf. of NAACP v. Fayette Cty. Bd. of Commโrs, 775 F.3d 1336, 1342 (11th Cir. 
 
- 3 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 8 of 31
 
2015).2 Under Defendantโs novel standard, a stateโs compliance with Section 2 
would hinge on whether, at the time a given map is drawn, minority legislators 
propose the right maps and provide the right analysis in support of an additional 
majority-minority districtโnotwithstanding their own desires as incumbents. See 3 
Tr. 604:25-605:3 (โ[E]very elected official wants the best district for their election. 
Theyโre  not  thinking  about  whatโs  the  best  district  for  all  black  people . . .โ) 
(Sanders). Nothing in Section 2 indicates Congress intended to foist upon any 
individual  legislator,  regardless  of  their  race,  the  singular  responsibility  for 
determining what the VRA does and does not require whenever a new map is drawn.  
Thus, contrary to Defendantโs unsupported assertions, Section 2 neither asks 
why  the  Alabama  Legislature  failed  to  create  a  second  majority-minority 
congressional district in 2011, nor provides a defense based on the assertion that it 
would have been politically difficult to pass a plan with two such districts.3 Instead, 
it simply asks whether the map dilutes African Americansโ voting strength, even if 
                                                 
2 To be sure, Representative Sewell supports Plaintiffsโ claim in this case. PX129. 
3 Similarly, Defendantโs argument that Plaintiffsโ Illustrative Plans would not have 
been precleared is a red herring. Legislatorsโ concerns about preclearance, well-
founded or not, offer no information about whether a given districting plan has a 
dilutive effect. 
 
 
- 4 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 9 of 31
 
that dilution is entirely inadvertent. The information considered by the Legislature 
at the time it drew the 2011 Plan therefore has no bearing on Plaintiffsโ claim.4 
B.  Defendantโs racial gerrymandering defense defies Eleventh Circuit 
law and would render Section 2 inoperative. 
Defendant further attempts to distract from the actual Section 2 standard by 
alleging the Illustrative Plans are racial gerrymanders. ECF No. 101 (โDef.โs Br.โ), 
at 5-12. But Defendant fails to identify a single case in which a court rejected a 
Section 2 claim because the plaintiffโs illustrative plan was drawn with too much 
focus on race. Instead, โvarious courts,โ including the Eleventh Circuit, โhave held 
that Section 2 plaintiffs in vote dilution cases are not required to show that their 
proposed plans comply with Miller v. Johnson to satisfy Gingles One.โ Terrebonne 
Parish Branch NAACP v. Jindal, 274 F. Supp. 3d 395, 428-29 (M.D. La. 2017) 
(citing Davis v. Chiles, 139 F.3d 1414, 1425 (11th Cir. 1998)). 
                                                 
4 Contrary to Defendantโs suggestion, 1 Tr. 97:15-17, the Court considers 2010 
Census data under Gingles 1 not because it informs what โcould haveโ been drawn 
in 2011 but because decennial Census data are presumptively reliable throughout the 
decade. Dickinson v. Ind. State Election Bd., 933 F.2d 497, 503 (7th Cir. 1991) 
(census figures are โthe relevant data for assessing a claim under Section [2]โ); 
United States v. Town of Lake Park, Fla., No. 09-cv-80507-CIV, 2009 WL 3667071, 
at *3-4 (S.D. Fla. Oct. 23, 2009); compare Johnson v. DeSoto Cty. Bd. of Commโrs, 
204 F.3d 1335, 1341-43 (11th Cir. 2000) (holding district court did not err in 
considering data post-dating challenged plan where defendant provided โcompetent 
evidenceโ to overcome the presumption of the  โcontinuing accuracy of census 
figuresโ). 
 
 
- 5 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 10 of 31
 
Defendantโs  entire  argument  relies  on  the  assertion  that  Plaintiffs  โmust 
demonstrate the existence of a proper remedy,โ for which Defendant quotes Davis. 
Def.โs Br. at 5. But not only does Defendant take that quotation out of context, the 
Davis court expressly rejected Defendantโs exact argument. In Davis, the plaintiffs 
challenged at-large judicial election systems and offered a Gingles illustrative plan 
containing a majority-minority district. 139 F.3d at 1416, 1418. The district court 
rejected the claim on two independent grounds. First, the defendantsโ interests in 
maintaining at-large judicial election systems outweighed the plaintiffsโ interest in a 
district-based scheme. Id. at 1419. Second, plaintiffsโ proposed districts were racial 
gerrymanders.  Id.  The  Eleventh  Circuit  affirmed  only  the  first  ground  after 
considering โFloridaโs interest in maintaining its Constitutionโs judicial selection 
system in determining whether Davis has proposed a permissible remedy.โ Id. at 
1421. As a result, the plaintiffs had not shown โthe existence of a proper remedy.โ 
Id. at 1419. That is the statement that Defendant quotes. See Def.โs Br. at 5-6. 
With regard to the second ground, the Eleventh Circuit found it โnecessary 
and appropriateโ to clarify that the district court had โmisread the applicable lawโ 
by โattempt[ing] to apply [racial gerrymandering] authorities such as Miller to this 
Section Two case.โ Davis, 139 F.3d at 1425. The racial gerrymandering doctrine 
does not apply to the first Gingles precondition, the court explained, because they 
 
- 6 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 11 of 31
 
โaddress very different contextsโ: while the former involves a challenge to excessive 
focus on race, the latter requires a plaintiff to create a new district with a minimum 
minority population of 50%. Id. Applying the racial gerrymandering doctrine to 
Section 2 would โpenalize [a plaintiff] . . . for attempting to make the very showing 
that Ginglesโ demands, and โwould . . . make it impossible, as a matter of law, for 
any plaintiff to bring a successful Section Two action.โ Id. Thus, applying the racial 
gerrymandering doctrine to the first Gingles precondition โmisinterpret[s] the law 
regarding the role of race in assessing permissible remedies for violations of Section 
Two.โ Id. at 1426.5 
                                                 
5 For this reason, the vast majority of the analyses performed by Defendantโs experts 
are irrelevant to this case. And in any event, the sheer number of courts that have 
rejected both expertsโ opinions should give the Court pause before crediting their 
testimony on any aspect of the case. See, e.g., Democratic Natโl Comm. v. Reagan, 
329 F. Supp. 3d 824, 837 (D. Ariz. 2018) (finding Dr. Hoodโs analysis was โnot 
usefulโ and โreflected an incomplete understandingโ and noting that โDr. Hoodโs 
testimony has been rejected or given little weight in numerous other cases due to 
concerns over its reliabilityโ). In fact, every court before which Dr. Johnson has 
testified has rejected some or all of his opinions. Common Cause v. Lewis, No. 18 
CVS 014001, 2019 WL 4569584, at *95-96 (N.C. Sup. Ct. Sept. 3, 2019) (rejecting 
Dr. Johnsonโs โmethodologies, analyses, and conclusionsโ because he had made โa 
series of significant errorsโ and noting courts in all four of the previous cases in 
which he had testified โhave rejected his analysisโ); see also Luna v. Kent, 291 F. 
Supp. 3d 1088, 1109 (E.D. Cal. 2018) (rejecting his communities-of-interest analysis 
in the only other Section 2 case in which Dr. Johnson has testified); Covington v. 
North Carolina, 283 F. Supp. 3d 410, 449 (M.D.N.C. 2018) (finding his racial 
gerrymandering analysis โunreliable and not persuasiveโ). Indeed, when asked about 
 
 
- 7 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 12 of 31
 
Defendantโs reasoning illuminates the Eleventh Circuitโs concerns. Under 
Defendantโs wholly unsupported theory, the only scenario in which Section 2 applies 
is when a plan contains a district that is nearly majority-minority. Def.โs Br. at 10. 
According to Defendant, a new majority-minority district is permissible only when 
it entails tinkering โon the margins of the [existing] districts.โ Id. But if that were 
the standard, Section 2 would apply only when it is needed the least; a plan that 
severely  cracks  a  minority  population  among  several  districtsโlike  the  one 
challenged hereโwould be insulated from Section 2 review. As Davis makes clear, 
that is not, and cannot be, the law. Thus, โ[n]otwithstanding the polemics regarding 
race-based redistricting that pervade [Defendantโs] brief to this [C]ourt,โ the racial 
gerrymandering doctrine has no role in the Gingles preconditions. Davis, 139 F.3d 
at 1424-25.6  
                                                 
the  Common  Cause  courtโs  rejection  of  his  opinions,  Dr.  Johnson  responded 
untruthfully. 5 Trial Tr. 1038:16-24. 
6 As explained in Plaintiffsโ Pre-Trial Brief, even if this Court were to ignore 
Eleventh Circuit law and apply the racial gerrymandering doctrine in this case, 
Defendantโs argument would still fail. Pls.โ Br. at 33. Race did not predominate in 
the Illustrative Plans because, as explained in Section III.A, each complies with 
traditional redistricting principles. And even if race did predominate, it was justified 
by the compelling interest of complying with Section 2. Davis, 139 F.3d at 1425 
n.23. Contrary to the Reapportionment Committeeโs Guidelines referring to the 
VRA as a โcompelling state interest,โ PX084 ยง IV.7.d, Defendant appears to assert 
 
 
- 8 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 13 of 31
 
C.  The cause of racially polarized voting is legally irrelevant, and, in 
any event, the undisputed evidence established a strong connection 
between partisanship and race in Alabama. 
Plaintiffs are not required to prove that the undisputed racially polarized 
voting in the State results from particular racial attitudes. See Pls.โ Br. at 34-35. The 
Gingles plurality explicitly held that the motivations of voters are irrelevant to 
determining whether racially polarized voting exists, and no majority of the Eleventh 
Circuit has ever imposed such a requirement. Id. Defendant asks this Court to create 
a new legal standard requiring Section 2 plaintiffs to affirmatively demonstrate that 
individual voters are driven by race. Def.โs Br. at 20-21. But this would be a near 
impossible showing. This was a primary reason why Congress created the effects-
based claim under which Plaintiffs bring this suit: any required showing of intent on 
the part of legislators or the public โis unnecessarily divisive because it involves 
charges of racism on the part of individual officials or entire communities, [] places 
an  inordinately  difficult  burden  of  proof  on  plaintiffs,  and  []  asks  the  wrong 
question.โ  Gingles,  478  U.S.  at  43-44  (internal  quotation  marks  and  citations 
omitted).  Instead,  whether  vote  dilution  is  โon  account  of  race  or  colorโ  is 
determined by the objective Senate Factors. Nipper, 39 F.3d at 1524, 1526. 
                                                 
that Section 2 compliance is not a compelling state interest, Def.โs Br. at 8. No court 
has ever taken that position; this Court should not be the first. 
 
- 9 - 
  

Case 2:18-cv-00907-KOB     Document 116     Filed 12/13/19     Page 14 of 31
 
Even if the  motivations behind racially polarized voting were  a relevant 
consideration, it is Defendantโs burden to prove that race is not a factor. Nipper, 39 
F.3d at 1524-26 & nn.60, 64. Here, Defendantโs own expert testified he could not 
support that position; when asked whether, based on his research, he could say race 
is not a factor in votersโ choice of political parties, he answered, โNo, certainly not.โ 
5 Tr. 957:9-11 (Hood). Dr. Hood further testified that white southerners transitioned 
to the Republican party after passage of the VRA โprimarily [as] a function of racial
